user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I'm having trouble understanding why Firefox tries to hide tls certificate info away from the user.    With a DV cert, clicking on the padlock displays e.g. for mozilla.org:    Mozilla Foundation    (Secure Connection)        This information is already conveyed by the green padlock and the "Mozilla Foundation (US)" text next to the full URL, so clicking on the padlock doesn't actually, as a user, give me any meaningful info (it actually gives me *less*).        To get to the issuer name and other cert details, I have to 1) click the padlock and 2) click the arrow next to Secure Connection. Why not display that in the first level of the padlock menu?        With a non-DV cert, the situation is even worse (e.g. with https://www.videolan.org) as the two clicks will only give me the cert issuer's name, nothing else.        For mixed content (e.g. https://www1.sunrise.ch/), I'll get a warning that the connection is not secure when clicking on the padlock/warning sign. Going down to the second menu won't give me any more information (the same warning message is repeated and I can't even see the issuer's name).        Could we maybe merge both levels of the padlock menu?    It seems that if a user merely wanted to check if the connection was secure, the green padlock is all they would look for. Forcing them through two clicks/levels to get a bit more info seems like a waste.        Also, reaching the Certificate Viewer to get proper cert details takes me 4 (!) clicks starting from the padlock and I really need to know what to look for.    While I do agree that most users won't understand that info or won't look for it, I'm surprised it is buried so deep. The same goes for TLS version/ciphers (requires 3 clicks).        I am well aware that Mozilla did a bunch of UX research before making these choices, I thought I'd just drop my 2 cents in. Is there any forum or mailing list where these UX choices are being discussed?

description: I keep trying to go to regular, well known websites like Facebook, Google, and etc, but it keeps giving me this error message: "This Connection is Untrusted        You have asked Firefox to connect securely to www.google.com, but we can't confirm that your connection is secure.        Normally, when you try to connect securely, sites will present trusted identification to prove that you are going to the right place. However, this site's identity can't be verified.    What Should I Do?        If you usually connect to this site without problems, this error could mean that someone is trying to impersonate the site, and you shouldn't continue.        This site uses HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to specify that Firefox only connect to it securely. As a result, it is not possible to add an exception for this certificate.        www.google.com uses an invalid security certificate.        The certificate is not trusted because the issuer certificate is unknown.    The server might not be sending the appropriate intermediate certificates.    An additional root certificate may need to be imported.        (Error code: sec_error_unknown_issuer)"        This is really bugging me because Firefox is supposed to be better than Microsoft Edge and my dad won't let me download Google Chrome.  So I'm kinda stuck.

description: Firefox had always previously made me very happy.  NOW IT IS JUNK!  I have four MAJOR ISSUES with it.          1) It now always without exception looses my options settings when it updates since the very first version where they are stored 'in the cloud'.        2) I bought a computer with a hard drive to store MY DATA!  I DON'T WANT MY DATA, ANY OF IT, FORCED INTO THE CLOUD ON SOMEONE ELSE'S SERVER!  I never had problem one while settings were stored on my machine.        3) Every time the options are reset, this is a HUGE WASTE OF MY TIME!  And, no, I will NOT ENROLL IN SYNC!  I have consistently and vigorously refused and removed all applications that use the so called cloud, which is most likely a huge invasive privacy hole.        4) For this reason, I have begun searching for a truly secure Web browser to use in place of Firefox which will store MY DATA ON MY HARD DRIVE!  I have no sympathy for those lame enough to want a netbook or mobile phone to surf the Web on.  Let them use the mobile phone version!          For this reason, and since there has been no movement to a branch I'm willing to use, all the machines I own and support from now on will have some other Web Browser installed.  That is about 134 units lost.  Have a NICE DAY somewhere else!

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: Firefox 42.0 "Mozilla Firefox for Ubuntu" canonical - 1.0 under Ubuntu 15.04.        The browser now (in the past week or two) locks up when requested to enter Full Screen if not running under any window manager (or when running under an old window manager such as vtwm that doesn't have all the modern hooks).        Reproduce:        1. Start up Ubuntu 15.04 with the full Unity desktop installed.    2. Clean out (remove or rename) $HOME/.mozilla to start clean.    3. Open Firefox.    4. Note that using F11 correctly resizes Firefox to Full Screen and back down.    5. Kill the window manager: run: initctl stop unity7    6. Return to Firefox and try F11 or turn on "Full Screen" from the menu.    7. Browser locks up.        Changing tabs doesn't refresh the screen unless you do something to    trigger an X11 refresh such as opening a menu.  F11 does *not* undo the    damage - the browser stays locked up.  Using the Firefox menu to disable    (un-check) "Full Screen" also does nothing.  Nothing works.        8. Start an old window manager such as "vtwm".  No change.  Firefox is    still locked up.    9. Exit vtwm.    10. Re-start the Unity window manager: run: initctl start unity7    11. Return to Firefox and use F11 or the menu "Full Screen" a few times and Firefox is working again.    12. Repeat as needed.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0 Iceweasel/42.0
description: I like to donate to Open Source projects. But today Firefox asked me to donate to Mozilla and I just couldn't do it. Why? Mozilla has partnerships with big companies already and seem well suited to maintain the Firefox browser and the Thunderbird MUA. But that's the thing: browser/MUA *maintenance* is all I wish for, but instead the money is spent on new features. In the last 10 years of Firefox development none of the "new features" helped me do my work better. So instead of developing, *maintaining* the Mozilla products (fixing security issues, keeping up with web standards) would be sufficient and the partnerships with these big companies should be sufficient to pay for it.        These 10 bucks I would have donated I can now donate to an open source project that really needs it. Asking for money just because everybody else is (esp. this time of the year) isn't helping, it's wasting resources.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I'm a site developer. We have an ecommerce site. Many of our users are not technically savvy and we do our best to be very clear and succinct in the information we display.        I was very disappointed to learn how Firefox handles the window.onbeforeunload event as first implemented in this bug report (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=588292).        Unfortunately the message provided by FF is more confusing for my customers than it is helpful. When a customer gets to the review page some have a tendency to think the order is place and leave. We use onbeforeunload to show the message 'Your order has not been placed. Are you sure you want to leave?'.  However the Firefox message says 'data will not be saved'. For these customers that are already confused because of not reading the page carefully this message is nonsensical, even spammy.        I understand the behavior was set for a reason, it has been that way for some time, and the discussion about it 2 years ago cause a raucous. But is there no way this behavior can be presented for consideration again?  Other browsers fight the phishers by pre/postfixing the site-defined message with clear notices and well marked buttons. Is that method not good both for developers and users?

description: Firefox is in the forefront of innovative thoughtful progress.  My question though, concerns the maneuvering, intentional or unintentional, which forces the loss of Firefox despite preferences:  The pernicious code attacks on Windows and Microsoft products, and some Apple products like the dual-core, that causes uncontrollable cursor movements, cursor clicks/selects items and travels across/up the screen without input of any sort, moves the cursor when a finger is more than 3" away from the touchpad inplying enormous radiation near the brain, forces a move to a Chromebook; either that or laying out $1000+ for something the local gang, like in Portland Oregon, is guaranteed to ruin within 24 hours with traces of strychnine or nerve gas or other poisons or stenches.  There is no standalone Firefox such that can run on a Chromebook at present, and so forces the loss of Firefox, along with privacy thereof like SDC, Ghostery and several other, ability to download videos Chrome doesn't have and much else. The implied trend towards mandatory advertising and no free downloads of videos would seem to be implied in losing Firefox for more "domesticatable" items; in other words, a concrete step towards the latter.  I donated because of my well-rewarded use of Firefox so far, but see no way to continue. The psychological separation and programming from a jittery malfeasant malicious cursor cannot be endured even for Firefox.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I'm rather surprised that, for the most part, of the browsers I'm familiar with, the interface for bookmarks is so "behind the times". The toolbar has it's uses, mainly for visiting the same sites frequently, however takes up screen real estate and, along with my primary concern, doesn't allow a very friendly or intuitive way to find those important pages you save, knowing you'll need them later on in life, but should rarely see the light of day. One could argue to simply use the menu whilst avoiding the toolbar for its given downsides, or some other method I may be unfamiliar with. Contrary to those statements, in my most honest opinion, the menu's do not provide much comfort either. Now I could be considered an amateur and that could be the very reason for my difficulties. Considering though that my experiences may also be affecting a fair portion of other users, I do believe it to be of interest to further investigate this issue.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: First I will give my suggestion, and then I will explain the reasons for it below that.        My suggestion is an addition to the plugin check page, a 4th column which lists the actual live current version of each plugin. Perhaps this column could be optional and disabled by default, but I wouldn't think so.        The current plugin check version numbers are manually maintained by mozilla, and sometimes there will be a lag time of 2 days, perhaps sometimes due to a minor compatibility issue with the plugin such as the current tab muting issue with flash. So, this new extra list for the 4th column could also be manually maintained, it would just be a lot quicker because nobody needs to check anything, they just keep that column up to date. OR, there could be a more automated solution, such as a system where plugin makers will use an API or something where they are responsible for filling in the new version each time they make a release, Or, perhaps you could use some kind of scraper that checks the vendor web page once an hour or something like that.         With my suggestion, everything could work the way it does now, with Firefox catching up and/or vetting new plugin versions just like they do now, but with the additional column the user would be empowered with more accurate information.            The reason for my suggestion is that the way the Plugin Check page and feature presents itself is as a true live check against current versions of the plugins.        When you go to Add-ons Manager, it has a link that says "Check to see if your plugins are up to date". When you click on that it goes to the plugin check page. Between that link text and everything presented on the plugin check page, it completely gives the user the impression that the plugin check is actually checking to see if your plugins are literally up to date - ie: when it shows the green thumbs up and tells you your version of Flash is up to date, the user thinks that 100% their flash is up to date, and that if they checked on the Adobe site, there would not be a newer version.        But that is not always the case. Firefox manually maintains a list of current plugin versions, and it can sometimes lag two days behind. Hence my suggestion above.        The problem is that users are not getting accurate information, and not only that, they are sometimes getting misinformation, where they will think they have the latest version when they don't. This is a somewhat important issue because when a plugin releases a security patch that solves you know, 80 security flaws, you don't want the user to think they are protected from those when they aren't.

When you take away functionality from something as fundamental as copy and paste you must expect queries on how to return and FIX the problems you just created for a function that has been there for multi years.  Surely it's NOT unreasonable to be able to copy material from a web site with all the attendant embedded links and formatting and paste it into say a word or other type of document. Why would you remove such a function???        Virtually EVERYDAY you take something AWAY.  It's getting beyond ridiculous. Making Firefox less and less useful to the average user is NOT desirable behaviour. Pointless change for the sake of it?

description: One thing that I do a lot of is copy & paste in the browser.  I can do this leaning back in my chair without ever having to use my keyboard.  But then after I paste I have to lean forward in my chair to press the Enter key, after which I can lean back in my chair again.  There really, really needs to be a place on the screen where I can point my mouse cursor and click, which is the equivalent of pressing the enter key, so that I don't have to keep doing this the rest of my life.  This should be found in the Customize area so that others who share my view of this can also choose to be able to cut, paste and Enter while remaining comfortably reclined while using the browser.        I know a thing or two about software interfaces, but I'm not a programmer, else I would do this myself.  Here's a picture of me showing off something I designed 30 years ago which is now in common use worldwide because it was chock full of my ideas about how we should be able to interact with computers.  https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Comdex_1986.png

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I use the share feature a lot (little paper airplane).  I can't tell you the number of times I had a nice post typed out on Facebook, but hit an erroneous key, or want to check some feature or information on another tab, and reflexively click on it.  Immediately the "share it" window closes, and I lose everything I'd typed in, and have to start over.  Yes, I have sort of curbed doing it, but like with switching on a light switch during a power failure, I still do it.        Add the fact I can by typing on the page, and hit an erroneous key and the window will snap shut, all of my typing lost, and it can be frustrating.  I guess it's human nature, but most of the time the second offering is just an aborted shorthand attempt at recreating something like I had, with irritation included.        Question is--isn't there some way you can do this where I can check other tabs, then come back and finish my share on the tab I am sharing?  And perhaps stall it's shutting with some sort of warning, requiring a click,when I hit some odd key on the bottom row (usually, I'm guessing, because I type pretty fast).  I wish you could address this, in your next update.        And yes, I generally love your browser, all the features, other than that I like the built-in share thing, I like the syncing between computers, it's great.          Thanks,     James

description: Now that FirefoxOS is dead, is there ANY reason to keep Australis around anymore?  I would really like Firefox to look, feel, and behave like a native app again.  There's also no reason for the browser chrome to use more screen pixels than the web content.  Lets declare the huge round tabs dead and move on.  Gigantic icons have their place on touch devices and children's toys, or to improve accessibility, but a "small icons" mode is essential for integration with the native OS, and essential for laptop users with small screens.        Thanks, and best of luck in your endeavours to save Firefox.

description: Same Same as previously. Listen to feedback?????? The last fifteen + days at least I can NO LONGER copy and paste txt etc from a website with HTML in it and have that HTML formatting show up in the pasted document into a Thunderbird Email.  What have you done with that function?  How do I fix it in about:config or other settings to get my functionality back and WHY have you removed the + from the new tab button.  Both Still present in earlier versions. WHY remove these things and if you want to change the BASE function that has been there forever why not give the user the OPTION to put it back how it was?????        When you take away functionality from something as fundamental as copy and paste you must expect queries on how to return and FIX the problems you just created for a function that has been there for multi years.  Surely it's NOT unreasonable to be able to copy material from a web site with all the attendant embedded links and formatting and paste it into say a word or other type of document. Why would you remove such a function???        Virtually EVERYDAY you take something AWAY.  It's getting beyond ridiculous. Making Firefox less and less useful to the average user is NOT desirable behaviour. Pointless change for the sake of it?

description: I use Linux Mint 17.3.  I switched to Linux when Windows XP was discontinued.  I didn't think I'd like Linux Mint as much as I do now, and I can't imagine ever switching back to Windows though.        My issue with Firefox is DRM and not being able to watch Netflix on Firefox.  I currently view Netflix on Google Chrome, and to be honest, I wouldn't use Google Chrome if it weren't my only choice in viewing Netflix.  However, since Firefox doesn't support DRM with Linux... I'm stuck using Google Chome.        I'd love it if Firefox, if possible, would rethink its current stance on DRM and Linux systems and come out in an update with at least an option for users like me who love your browser and use Linux as their operating system, and feel Firefox is limited by this one small thing.  I know that Firefox has allowed users with Windows and Apple to have DRM, but not Linux.  I'm not a technically savvy person, and I don't know if there's limitations to Linux which makes it impossible to add DRM to the Firefox browser, but if there isn't, I'm certainly a user that would love to have this option.        Thank you!    -E. Spendlove

description: First, please don't have people clicking on smiley faces in order to give feedback  It's just silly  Second, the reason for the feedback is I cannot stand the changes made to Firefox OPTIONS menu under the tools drop-down menu. I absolutely hate how this new tab that comes up when going into the options menu takes you back to the starting menu almost like you've never used it before.  I also cannot stand that it's a tab and not the window I liked.  It's just terrible!  PLEASE CHANGE IT BACK!!!. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I am just about ready to quit Firefox permanently. I am tired of how often it doesn't respond and now, after I took your suggestion to refresh, I can no longer put the tabs on the bottom like I used to. I absolutely HATE having the tabs on the top, which is why I used to go to the about:config and turn it off. But you, in your infinite wisdom, have completely removed this option. It is beyond ridiculous. If I wanted to use a browser that acted like Chrome I would, but I guess, since you seem to keep moving in that direction, I really should. At least they don't seem to have the issues your browser does with things like Flash, which I have waited several years for you to fix, to no avail. In addition, on the blank tab page, not only are all the pinned tabs gone but you've now added advertising in the form of suggested sites, advertising that I cannot remove. Yes, Mozilla, Firefox, we are done. Consider this a farewell letter from a dissatisfied long-time customer.

description: It made me sad. But now I'm happy. I've had trusteer (recommended by my bank), and one pass extensions working for ages. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: The error message that tells me the following -         "A script on this page may be busy, or it may have stopped responding. You can stop the script now, open the script in the debugger, or let the script continue."        is next to useless! It tells me the URL of the link to the script that is causing the problem BUT it does not tell me which tab or website I have opened that contains that link. GIVE me a button that takes me to the tab (brings it forward) so that I can decide what to do about it. (most likely I will just want to close it and perhaps reopen it.) Without that sort of info I have a very difficult time tracking down what website has that piece of script junk that has stopped working, especially if/when I have a LOT of tabs/websites already opened.        Furthermore, telling a user that he/she has the option to stop a script, or let it continue is also useless! 99% of your users will HAVE NO IDEA what those options mean, what they will do, let alone what to do! This is a technical failure, users are clueless about answering such technical questions, AND THAT IS THE WAY IT SHOULD BE! Far better to simply ask the user if they want to close the connection to the website causing the problem, wait awhile longer, and/or reload the page.        Please try to develop software, and establish a policy that requires code to be written from the perspective of a user who DOES NOT have a degree in computer science! Keep messages and options simple, don't yap about "scripts", most poor users have no idea what the hell a script is. And for goodness sake DON'T ASK A USER IF THEY WANT TO DEBUG THE SCRIPT! That is a very advance feature that should be made available only to someone sophisticated enough to know how to.        P.S. I DO have an advance degree in computer science, been a software developer for over 40 years now, and EVEN I DO NOT KNOW HOW TO RESPOND TO THIS MESS WHEN IT HAPPENS OTHER THAN TO TAKE A GUESS.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: Please consider the following scenario.        I have about 5 computers (in different places) in which I have my own account and eventually Firefox Sync configured:          - PC1 with golden bookmarks in state 1 (current)      - PC2 with old bookmarks in state 2 (outdated)      - PC3 with old bookmarks in state 3 (outdated)      - PC4 with old bookmarks in state 4 (outdated)      - PC5 with old bookmarks in state 5 (outdated)        FF Sync server state is outdated also.        I turn on Sync in PC1. What I get is a merge between state 1 and server state:      - current folders are merged with old folders that I removed many months ago;      - current bookmarks are merged with old bookmarks that I also removed many months ago;      - bookmarks that I moved from folder A to folder B will appear in both folders A and B.        OK, let's assume I restore the correct state.        Then I will turn on Sync in PCs 2 to 5, one at a time. I will have the same problem, and I'll have to correct the merge 4 more times.        Doing this is an extremely difficult and frustrating task.        I think you agree that this does not make sense. This could be easily solved with a simple switch like Xmarks provides. See the 1st screenshot from: http://www.makeuseof.com/tag/4-great-ways-sync-bookmarks-favorites-computers-phones/. If this switch didn't make sense, it would not be provided by Xmarks.        What I suggest does not impact current architecture, since it's an option, not a mandatory behavior.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: It's not my problem it is a problem with Firefox.     I am using FF version 42.0 on XP sp3. Having seen FF users complaining about Firefox's high CPU utilization. I decided to take a quick look at what is going on, and behold, yes it does use a lot and a lot of CPU. Like 40-60% total CPU of a dual core with four instances of Firefox running with a total of 20 tabs. The only other window was Task manager, from where my CPU data comes.    All four instances of FF were in full screen mode so that only one tab from one instance was on the screen at any one time.     Now here is the interesting part.     When I hit "Show Desktop", and all window instances were minimized, the total CPU immediately went down to 3% to 9%.     When I hit "Show Desktop" again, restoring the status of the desktop, the total CPU used by Firefox went back up to the 40% to 60% utilization.     I did this a dozen times and the result where always the same.    I thought you may want to know.    PS: It would be nice is you sent me a copy of this to my email, I shall see.

description: Hi there,            I have been a very satisfied Firefox user, until this morning, when things got weird, and hard for me.         Since this morning, while reading the news on one website I cannot see if I have received an email, for example, because the labels from the top of the screen have disappeard. Now, to see if I have received an email I need to move my pointer to the top of the screen, so I can see the labels from the other websites I have open too. Not good... :/        And that is not the only problem: Now, I cannot see what time it is on my computer either, or I cannot click on Start at the bottom of the screen while visiting a website because there is nothing at the bottom of the screen either! Again, to see what time it is now  I need to move my pointer to the top of the screen, and minimise or close the website I'm reading to be able to see what time it is, or to being able to click on Start to open Windows Office or my Sticky Notes or Skype, etc. Pretty bad. :(        I apologise for not writing to you before saying how happy I was with Firefox, but I trully was. It is the one and only browser I have used since...forever! :)        Please, put everything back the way it was, and thank you for trying. You cannot improve perfect!  ;)        Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to all of you. :D        Marianna

description: Hello. I've really loved Firefox for years, it's been my browser of choice, and I've recommended it to many others.        But today, upgrading to 43.0 on Windows 10, I am quite unhappy.        Three of my add-ons were disabled because they aren't "signed". Security feature, that's nice. But they are security add-ons - specifically, Kaspersky, my paid protection service, anti-malware, etc.        I can re-enable them - but only by completely disabling the check for whether add-ons are signed.        Please give me a "white list" option instead! I shouldn't have to disable Firefox's security measures to have trusted add-ons active. Thank you.        (Link included to article about why "unsigned" add-ons are being disabled automatically, and that the entire security feature must be disabled to re-activate trusted add-ons.)

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Using Firefox on Mac OS X 10.6.8. Dumped all other browsers years ago. You folks have the dubious honor of being the first time in years that I've been coerced to accept a "cookie", which I will dump the second after I send this. ("Sure we can support you, just let us jam this cookie down your throat first.") I don't accept cookies or "register" on any website, and thanks to that great Ghostery add-on I block all trackers, beacons, analystics and other unsolicited garbage that "normal" people swallow without a peep.        No that I've paid your price, here's the problem.         I just clicked and accepted a Firefox update from v42 to v43. And CNN is now invisible, Firefox loads a blank page. Nada. Zip. I checked another dozen bookmarked websites and they still work fine. I tried unblocking all 8 beacons, trackers and analytics CNN loads on viewers that the Ghostery add-on blocks, individually and entirely. Still nothing.         So now I've downloaded what purports to be Firefox v42 from your website. When I unzip the file I end up with no less than 59 items of gobbledy-gook, and I'm not an engineer. It used to be a simple matter to install from the unzipped install app. Just find the easy to spot Firefox app icon and drag it to my apps folder and allow it to replace the version currently there. But with this unzipped file there's no Firefox app icon anywhere to be seen in any of the unzipped v42 folder.        How do I switch back to v42 if I can't find the Firefox app icon in the unzipped file folder? I don't want to open any of the 59 items of gobbledy-gook because I don't want to lose my Firefox prefs configuration or my bookmarks.        Please answer soon as I want to have access to CNN again. Then I'll wait 6mths before allowing another update, to give you time to iron out this bug in v43. It definitely isn't due to any problem at my end. Thanks. One of my gmail addresses below (and never mind how I get around Gmail's cookie coercion.)        Joe Shmoe        PS - Sorry, can't make a donation. $800/mth in old age pension doesn't go far.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: A few versions back you introduced a new format for the search engine list. It interfered with my daily work. If the last thing I had searched was a minor planet number at jpl and I switched amazon it auto searches for same thing at amazon. I got some help and was told all I need to do was change browser.search.showOneOffButtons;false and that solved my issue. Now with the update from 42 to 43 that now longer works. A user should be able to make customization to a their needs. This new behavior has nothing to do with security and therefor should not be forced on a user. Perhaps to some it is an improvement.      I have used 'add to search bar'  as I am sure many user have.  We all know that little window is for searching, therefor we do not need a little icon to show that, What we all need to see is the icon of the search engine we select before we start typing in the box. After all    if I am searching for selenium powder I will start at Amazon, not wiki or yahoo.        Not seeing the icon causes another issue if you don't clear the window before you change search engines, an unintended search is automatically performed in the wrong place.      Also when you change the search engine How do you know it actually changed.    Consider a list of 18 places, you have to find the icon that is not shown in the group to know that is the one you are on. That really seems counter-intuitive.      I immediately uninstalled 43 which means I miss out the the improved security of 43.    It interfered with my work. I re-installed 42 and disable updates. Long time since you forced me to do that.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Just a quick note about the default folder the english (UK) x64 version attempted to install to - it tried to install to:    C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Mozilla Firefox.        Anything in C:\\Program Files (x86) is EXPECTED to be 32 bit and putting a 64 program in here may cause problems. That said I think it's mainly a problem if 32 bit programs are installed into C:\\Program Files\\ (it might not load properly) but it's probably best to get it right from the start

description: Please do not precede with add-on signing. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I know it almost certainly won't be, but please restore the functionality of the "browser.search.showOneOffButtons" about:config preference.  The inability of the "new" search bar to easily, with the mouse, select the search engine before searching, and the lack of any concept of a "currently selected" search engine without changing the primary default are somewhat minor but infuriating regressions in usability for me.  So alternately, please provide ways to replicate this functionality in the new search bar.  (And once again displaying the icon for the currently selected search instead of the generic magnifying glass would probably be necessary if a "currently selected" search was restored.)        More preemptively, please provide some supported way to remove the new "Search For..." entry from the urlbar dropdown.  For me, it just takes up screen estate and reduces the number of the actual options I am looking for that I can see.  If I was going to search, I would use the search bar.  I am currently using the browser.urlbar.unifiedcomplete about:config preference to remove it, but it sounds like I am just setting myself up for another update to disable this preference also (and potentially missing out on backend improvements).

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I have been a loyal Firefoxer since the beginning. I haven't necessarily liked all the minor aesthetic changes made over the years, but they rarely crossed the line into annoying or workflow disrupting. I can't say the same for v43.         The address bar functionality was near-flawless before...What is the purpose of making needless changes to it?         Now when you type a single character to get to the address in your history beginning with that letter that is visited most frequently, instead of the useful function of using the site header and presenting the address like any other entry in the browser's history, it now strips the site header AND the most visited link at a particular domain in favor of bold text that says "Visit (Generic Domain Name)". Stripping away one of the most useful functions of the program is inexplicable!        It may not even seem a significant change to a casual user, but for someone like me who has a carefully choreographed workflow that they've developed within the program over many years, it is so disruptive that I will be forced to downgrade and refuse future updates.         Can't tell you how disappointed I am with Mozilla. Bordering on anger, actually. This change is 100% a deal-breaker for me in terms of being an updated user going forward. PLEASE, fix this ridiculous feature and return functionality to the address bar! I can't be the only one who has a real problem with the careless changes made to v43!        ***In the future, I hope you remember that change for the sake of change where no functional improvement has resulted is one of the most infuriating mistakes that a developer can make in the eyes of the advanced user. To make a change that actually decreases functionality is essentially unforgivable.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: This is just my opinion and I'm very supportive of Mozilla so don't take it the wrong way.        I believe the "hijacking of the url bar" (for lack of a better term) is not very friendly to users who are already used to either searching directly or choosing from a drop-down of known sites.  This adds an additional delay to parse that "visit something" while, imho, providing virtually no value to the search process.        I don't think it should be a default or, if it is, it should be an easy option in the beginning instead of requiring someone to be a "power user" of sorts and go to about:config and toggle the browser.urlbar.unifiedcomplete flag.        Thanks for the hard work.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I've been using Firefox since around 2007. What initially attracted to me to the browser was how customizable it was. Having addons changed the way I browsed the internet. It was revolutionary.        Then things started pointlessly changing. Most noteworthy was taking away the search function from the URL bar way back when. I dealt with that by using the search bar more frequently. But then you changed the search bar to what it is now — a useless, cluttered mess that stripped away the browser's previously useable and pleasant search functionality.        I've fiddled with the about:config settings so much in the past few years that I can't even keep track of what I've done. Seems like I need to change something with every update.        Now, what I consider one of the final straws in making me seriously consider switching to Chrome, you've made this whole mess involving unsigned addons. You've taken away the one thing that brought me to Firefox in the first place. I've been a happy user for a long time now — almost 10 years — and now you're slowly turning what once was a respectable browser into a sinking ship.        I have no idea what you're thinking with these new updates. What does it take for Firefox's development team to realize they don't have to fix what isn't broken?        I feel silly getting angry over this, but it's just so stupid. Firefox is turning into an embarrassing mess.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: When browsing threads on a forum, Firefox seems to have a new behaviour when it comes to loading animated GIFs. When scrolling through a thread, Firefox suddenly will become unresponsive ("beachball") for a variable amount of time. I've figured out that this always happens right when I'm about to scroll to where an animated GIF is in the thread, and the unresponsive time seems to correlate with how large the GIF's file size is. So, it doesn't seem to want to continue rendering the page until the GIF is fully-loaded, which is not so good behaviour for a forum where GIFs tend to be in the tens of megabytes.        This seems to have started with Firefox 42.        Previously Firefox would simply show the GIFs frame-by-frame as they load, which is a much more sensible behaviour.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: In my opinion, the new search interface in Firefox 43 is a regression.  Up to     this version, Firefox would still honor the "browser.search.showOneOffButtons"     which I used to keep the old style of search box.        I use many different search engines that have the same icon.  For example,     Wikipedia in 3 different languages.  The new interface requires hovering with     the mouse or using the up/down arrows to find the right one.  With a lot of     search engines configured, the name appears at the top instead of where your     are looking.  This requires looking up and down to see if the mouse cursor is     hovering the right one.        Also, stating in version 43, there is no way to keep the last used search     engine; it always goes back to the default.        I sincerely don't see how the icons are an improvement over the old list     interface.  The long list of previous searches has no value for me.  With the     old interface, Firefox would complete the characters typed with possible     matches.  Using the Down key, you could select previous searches or matches     and using ALT-Down would show the list of search engines.        I hope I manage to explain the issues sufficiently clearly to prevent this     from being just a pointless rant.  Firefox is my browser of choice and I hope     to keep it that way!

description: Well, Firefox 43 disables the latest firebug 3 beta. This is simply stupid on your part. Your native developer tools are pretty poorly done and firebug built on top is a poor compromise but at least it improves the usefulness and user experience. I understand there is an override I can track down to force enabling of unsigned add-ons. I'll go use it, but this basically means Firefox 43 is the last version of Firefox I'll ever use on any regular basis. I'll have to install later versions to test web pages in (you guys still have enough non-compliance with standards that testing is required if you're a web developer) but I'll be done using it for actual browsing and I have already quit recommending it to my non-technical friends and clients. Since it's actually been proven that your add-on signing is basically security theater:        http://danstillman.com/2015/11/23/firefox-extension-scanning-is-security-theater?firefox-against-censorship        and since the usabilty continues to degrade, you've finally become irrelevant. You're on your way to becoming the next Opera. I actually wish you luck. If you survive the continued decline in usage ove rthe next few years maybe someone will eventually take over who cares about what your users want instead of what your internal developes want and will again make something relevant. I had hopes with FF 42 - you actually seemed to be focusing on real issue in the browser rather than user interface tweaks that no one cares about. Guess that was a fluctuation.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: It's been a slow downhill ride using firefox. I've just wanted something that is simple and just works. For the longest time, Firefox has been that to me. No insane UI, not too much feature creep. But the little things erode and my laziness butts heads with your changes. You switch from Google to Yahoo. Now I have to type "goo" and wait half a second to autocomplete to google to do a search instead of doing it from the search bar (yahoo search returns highly irrelevant results). Ok, I get it. You need to stop relying on Google for your income, and it wasn't doing them much good anyways. Now though, I can't autocomplete anymore without going down at least past the automatic "yahoo search for goo" to get to google, to do a google search. I'm sure (I pray) that there's an easier workflow here, but like I said, I'm lazy. I liked where you were for the past ~8 years and I don't like the hoops I have to jump through to get to a page that's in my mind but not in my search history or favorites. And the ones that ARE in my search history or favorites are also one more button press away. But the difference here is that if I don't press that magical down button when I'm trying to autocomplete, the results are disastrous.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: The tabs have once again moved to above the address bar. That doesn't make sense. The tab serves as the "handle" for the contents of a web page; the address bar takes you to other places. To have the tabs above the address bar separates the "oneness" of the web page content from its "handle". The hierarchy should be address bar, which can open up multiple tabs of web page contents, and with the tab and its content as a single entity

description: After updating to FF 43, everything changed for the worse.  All sites were hanging badly, YouTube would only play in 360p, and Netflix wouldn't even play. I see others having the same issue and are being offered extensive workthroughs that frankly, practically require one to be a developer. I hate to say it but I am transferring over all my bookmarks to Chrome as it has no problem playing videos. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:46.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/46.0
description: I've read / heard about the plan to kill Fx as we know it through the plans to bury xul/xpi ...    https://wiki.mozilla.org/WebExtensions/FAQ        As a non-programmer, I have no idea what's involved in updating or rewriting an extension for use with the new system.         As an end-user since the Netscape days, I can say categorically that if I can't use the extensions and themes I want without having to acquire a degree in computer science, I'll terminate my relationship with Fx as soon as the fun is gone.        As an English teacher at two technically oriented universities here in Berlin, Germany - one of Fx's last bastions in the Western world - I am in close contact with both users and multipliers. My "people" are a savvy group when it comes to computers and co., and many are aware of your plans. So far, no one I've spoken with is very sympathetic.        Over the past couple of years, a lot of changes to Fx have been perceived as both whimsical and arrogant among the hardcore, long-time contributors to the Mozilla Forum, and I don't think this is due to inertia or general antipathy to change. I'd say it's more related to questions about why investments are being made in areas seen as purely cosmetic (Australis / the new notification slide-out) when there are (as far as I know) bugs a decade old still lurking in the code.

description: Something I would like you to change is to allow us to modify the priority of search terms and autofill function in the search bar.        If I type, for example, an "M" in the search bar up top, the dropdown menu will give me a list of sites I visited in the past that begin with an "M". I would like the option to prioritize the different items in that dropdown menu by dragging the different "M" search options in order. In this, the autofill function should be set to (1) alphabetical by default, unless I visit a site significantly more often, in which case (2) the new default is the most visited "M" site, or (3) I manually set the highest priority "M" site by dragging it to the top of the priority list.        As I type further, for example by now typing "Mi", aka adding the letter "i", then a new priority list will drop down as suggested search terms, and I can now edit the priority of this new dropdown menu. In other words, each search term has its own dropdown menu which can have priorities set, and the autofill function of each new search term as you type will update the autofill as you type.         Please let me know if you would like elaboration/clarification on this.    Thanks!

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.9; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: Please bring back the option to revert to the old search bar, whether it's from about:config with the browser.search.showOneOffButtons property, or as a preferences setting. There are many users out there, including me, who find the new search bar (as of version 34 and up) very clunky, non-intuitive and slower to use than the previous version.        My main concerns with this new search system is that, unlike the old system, you don't have the ability to choose the engine PRIOR to entering a search query. This affects suggestions for search engines such as Wikipedia and Google, which generate completely different suggestions as they provide different types/forms of information. Having to switch engines through mouse clicks or sifting through your list with Ctrl/Cmd + Up/Down is just an extra step in searching, defeating the purpose of an integrated quick search bar to begin with!        Furthermore, I would prefer Firefox to leave the search bar set to the engine I last used. Since I switch between multiple search engines frequently, and make consecutive searches from this engine (though not enough to warrant setting a default engine) this feature is especially important. Additionally, showing the icon of the selected search engine instead of just a magnifying glass icon is much more efficient because at a glance, I know which engine I'm searching on.        With regards to the new search layout, the grid takes up more space than it needs to, especially if search suggestions are provided. I liked that the drop-down-list style of the old search bar leaves this space for suggestions, instead of search engine icons on top of suggestions. The less clutter I see on my screen, the better. Another reason I prefer the drop-down-list style of the search bar is that when selecting an engine, you see both the icon and the name of the search engine. For engines that have similar-looking icons (e.g. Urban Dictionary and Thesaurus), having the name helps me distinguish between the two at a glance so I know that I'm using the right search engine.         As a long-time user of Firefox (previously a Chrome user) I hope the Firefox team can make something of this feedback. I look forward to continued improvement of Firefox.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I'm not sure if this is due to a recent change or not, but I have only noticed this behavior recently.        When using Firefox I block all cookies by default and add domains to the whitelist as needed. At some point this whitelist has become VERY particular about which domains it will and won't allow to set cookies - subdomains must be separately whitelisted or they will be blocked. In addition, it treats "https://" as separate from "http://", and cares about if the "www" is included or not. This makes what could be a fast and simple operation into an exercise in trial and error.    For example, recently I tried to log in to www.gog.gom after clearing all cookies and preferences. It used to be enough to simply whitelist "gog.com", but this no longer works. After considerable trial and error, to actually allow this site to use cookies requires whitelisting some combination of the following:        http://www.gog.com    https://www.gog.com    http://gog.com    https://gog.com    http://login.gog.com    https://login.gog.com        I would hope and expect that the whitelist would allow cookies from all subdomains of an entry, so that simply "gog.com" covered all of the variants listed above. Then it is up to the user to be specific if they want to be specific. Or very broad if they want that.        So in short it would be of great help and convenience if the following features existed in Firefox:        1) A way to tell Firefox to allow cookies from all subdomains and http/https variants of cookie whitelist entries. If there's some technical or security reason why that is unwise then perhaps have it configurable for each whitelist entry individually.        2) A fast way to "allow cookies from this site" using clicks, ideally in a new button that could be placed in a toolbar where the user wants it (if they want it).        3) Sort the whitelist alphabetically by the highest level domain. It currently sorts from left to right, which means that "https://mozilla.org" is nowhere near "http://mozilla.org" or "https://input.mozilla.org" on the list. this makes the list very difficult to deal with.        Thank you for reading

description: I have finally come to realize that the reason why my user profile keeps being manipulated is due to my use of the Mozilla browser. First off, when I delete my user profile and start anew my user profile automatically records a 14 mb input. Then shortly after logging onto the internet there is a further 5 to 7 mb installed on my user profile. From there after a day or two of use my user profiles climbs up to around 30+ mb. At that point, I start losing the ability to see comments at different websites such as Accuweathers FB plugin, or with Disqus  it might take 5 or 6 attempts at logging on before Disqus sees me. Recently, I have had to open a second page and then log on again to make Disqus recognize me. This is all harassment and attempts to silence my voice in the catastrophic climate change argument by good left wing Democrats. This has been going on for years, but I will not allow them to silence my voice. This has meant that over the years, I have to constantly delete my C: drive and reinstall my backup. Lately, I do this every several days. However, recently at Whats Up with That a friend who knows what I do not know mentioned obliquely that I should use Chrome. I figured that his comment was meant for me so I tried Chrome after deleting Firefox and found that my user profile was no longer steadily be added to. I have come to enjoy your browser over the years. I do not look forward to giving up Firefox. A possible solution is my new refurbished computer with Win7 Pro professionally installed, may not have the problem I am experiencing with Win XP Pro which I installed. I have yet to start using it, but will do so soon. But why does Firefox manipulate my user profile, when Chrome does not?

description: Hello,        With the latest update, unsigned addons are blocked by default. I am in favor of that move, especially with the increase in browser hijackers and exploit kits designed to take advantage of browser weaknesses. However, there is an addon that I use regularly for Lansweeper (a network inventory and management tool) that is not signed. I've asked Lansweeper to create a signed addon, but in the meantime I'm forced to allow all unsigned addons just to use that one.        My suggestion is for Firefox to provide a way for users to allow unsigned addons on a per-addon basis rather than the all-or-none basis like it is now.        Thank you,        Jono

description: I am deeply unhappy with Firefox. I used the browser for years, and then a couple of months ago started having problems with the loading of some pages that require proxy services and authentication; Firefox would simply never resolve the pages. Since I need to access these pages for my job, I started using Chrome instead. Recently, I decided to try and see if I could return to the Firefox browser instead, and I find that I'm unable to load pages that have PDFs in popup windows. The popup windows open, but the PDFs simply won't open within the window. I'm beyond frustrated and having spent the better part of a day trying to troubleshoot this, I simply don't have any more time to waste. I need to access these pages to accomplish very simple work tasks, and the fact that I can't access them via Firefox means that I must completely abandon the Firefox browser. Yes, I've tried safe mode and refreshing and all those things. I'm really sorry to be leaving Firefox and to be forced to use Chrome, but how can I use a browser that simply won't load pages, for which trouble-shooting is so incredibly difficult? Goodbye, Firefox.  I'm sad to leave but have no choice.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: The browser.search.showOneOffButtons in about:config does not work anymore with this latest version of firefox.         I do not like the OneOffButton due to a few reasons:    1. I have a few search engines. I usually use a non-default search engine and use "Ctrl-K" to input the search term, followed by "Enter" to get the search result. This had been working very well to me.     2. If I want to change the search engine, I can use "Ctrl-UP" or "Ctrl-DOWN" to change the search engine.     3. Once the search engine is selected, it's very easy for me to do the search with it.         With OneOffButton, I have to:    use Ctrl-K to input the search term, then, use mouse, or UP/DOWN/LEFT/RIGHT buttons to select the search engine, which is very complicated and time costing.         This was why I set browser.search.showOneOffButtons to false and still using the old search style. I'm not sure it's a bug that the browser.search.showOneOffButtons does not work anymore, or it's decided to remove the original style. Please keep it.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I updated one of my browsers to 43.1 and found that it disabled some of my favorite older extensions because they are unsigned.   I get the reasoning behind this.   However, to retroactively enact it on addons/extensions already in use without the means to re-enable is so not what Mozilla use to be about.    You are saying you know and will decide what is best for me, because I am unable to make a good choice.        I found the current workaround "xpinstall.signatures.required" change the value from true to false in the about:config file.   However, I read that you are going to remove this option in v 44.        I want to urge you not to do as such.   If I am clever enough to be able to override the defaults, I think one can assume I am clever enough to make my own decisions.    I have watched over the years now as Firefox has removed option after option, instead deciding what is best for me.    If I want that I can install Safari or Chrome.   I use Firefox because I have the options, the ability to add extensions, some of which are old and I doubt that the developer is going to go through the hassle of certifying something they created years ago for free.   One of these that was disabled is something that simply remove the tab view when I have no tabs open.   I hate the screen space wasted by tab view and I always open new windows, never tabs.  You took away that option from me years ago, now you are taking away the extension to override that.        Really disappointed.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Hi. What's gone wrong? FireFox used to be slicker than oiled PVC but for the past 2 or 3 months it's OK (not great, but OK) when it starts but gradually gets slower & slower until I have to restart it. It's not the websites (waiting for google? come on guys...), the PC or my service. I can sit IE alongside on my screen, accessing the same websites over the same cable & get completely normal response times.    I think the problem may be something to do with threading - it doesn't seem to be working right.    Symptoms are:    let's say I'm googling "Fred Bloggs"    as soon as I enter "Fred" google lists some Freds I might have been asking about but wasn't (Astaire, Olsen Cruise Lines, etc)    at this point FireFox freezes; I can carry on typing "Bloggs" but the new text doesn't appear on the query box; I can't switch to a different tab in FireFox but other programs continue behaving as normal, so it's not something like running out of memory    after a **long** time (up to a minute, not a couple of seconds) the extra text ("Bloggs") appears in the query box, google posts a list of websites & normal service is resumed, though with the same very slow response    if I exit FireFox & restart it again it will be OK for a few minutes, then it will slow down again    I'd emphasise that IE, running alongside, behaves perfectly normally.    FYI, I'm running Win 7 (up to date) on a quad core AMD, 8Gb RAM, elderly but adequate XFX/Nvidia graphics card etc, all standard stuff. The Internet connection is cable broadband, guaranteed 20Mbps (but does sometimes slip below that) & generally seems to run at around 50 - 100Mbps. I run WinZip System Utilities every week to defrag the disc, tidy up the registry etc, & I have F-secure Safe malware protection, which claims I'm free of viruses etc.    Thoughts

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Dear members of the Mozilla community,        I cannot value too highly the great contribution of the Firefox developer community towards defeating the once-dominant Internet Explorer and creating a secure, feature-rich browser for beginners and power users alike. It has been my browser of choice for many years, and any experiment with a different browser left me unsatisfied.        Firefox has seen some radical UI changes over the years. I initially disagreed with many of them, but mostly, they did not take much getting used to because the general workflow was not affected significantly.        This, unfortunately, cannot be said about the complete removal of the old search bar that has been put in place recently. The new search does NOT improve the workflow - on the contrary, it complicates things at every level. Entering repeated searches into the same search engine (e.g., a translator - a very widespread use case) now involves pointing the mouse to the desired search engine after *every* single search request. This alone slows down the process considerably, compared to simply terminating your search request with <return>.        And then there is the problem of locating the correct search engine, because the new search bar displays only icons and no description. For example, can you tell the difference between the English and German Wikipedia in the screenshot (see link below)? Bet you can't. You have to hover over all the potential targets, one by one, and then choose the right one based on the tooltips. How can the developers fail to realise that this is *highly* impractical? The new search bar has added not one, but *two* time-consuming, counterintuitive and utterly unnecessary steps to a formerly simple and straight-forward workflow. I have yet to identify a situation where the new search provides a significant improvement over the old one. (The "solution" offered by a developer to temporarily change the default search engine via the <ctrl> and arrow keys - i.e., cycling through a long list of search engines one by one - misses the point entirely.)        And now, we can't even choose the old search via the showOneOffButtons flag in about:config. It has been removed despite widespread criticism. Joe Average probably doesn't care, but your slightly more experienced users do. I can't help but feel angry that this group of users is, apparently, ignored. Microsoft couldn't have done it better.        It would be a nice Christmas present to bring back the old search bar.        Thank you and happy Christmas,        Dominic

What made Firefox a great alternative in the old days was its focus on being small, smart and not crammed with garbage.  If you don't recognize what drew people to Firefox in the first place, they will just abandon it.        For what it's worth, I don't mind paying $30 or whatever to turn Firefox into "normal" software that stays out of my way.  I'm tired of the AdWare approach that has defined so much software in the last few years, and I'm sad to see Mozilla going the same way.  Stop showing me things at startup.  Stop prompting me.  Just Work.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Hello,        First let me say I've been using Firefox since it used to be called Firebird.  I like it it a lot, have recommended it to countless others and have donated $ to you guys.  That being said, when I install your latest updates, you deem my plugins as "unverified" and disable them, without even giving me the option of re-enabling them.  That is BS!  These plugins, such as NoScript, BetterPrivacy, PrivacyBadger, etc. are essential for me to use Firefox!  It's funny that they apparently were deemed okay in the last version of FF, but not now.  PrivacyBadger comes from the EFF (Electronic Frontier Foundation), whom I also donate to and whom I trust way more than just about everyone else, including Mozilla.  I put up with FF's slowness as compared to Chrome, memory leaks, etc., so that I can use these plugins.  If you disable them, why do I need or want Firefox?        Thanks for reading/listening to my rant.  Can you tell I'm frustrated?    :-)        Best regards,    Stan

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.8; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: A number of versions ago you redesigned the search bar. It sucked, but at least we had a way to revert to the old format, so it wasn't that big a deal. Now you've taken that option away and suddenly the problem has gone from being 'no big deal' to being a full-blown 'deal breaker'. For those of us that have several sites that don't have an icon, and others that share the same one (like the different language versions of Wikipedia) the stupid grid you have forced upon us just is a nightmare (half the time I don't know if I'm searching in wikipedia in English, Spanish, German or French). I'm trying Classic Theme Restorer, and that has sort of solved the problem, but it also seems to be mucking my browser's performance. I'm giving it forty-eight hours to see if I can live with the add-on, if I can't I'll be reverting to 42. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: The latest update significantly altered the way the way the address bar works in a way that makes Firefox more difficult to use.        Whilst previously I could just type in the first few letters of a frequently visited site and hit down then enter, knowing the first choice would be the one I wanted; now it's not so simple. Firefox now automatically selects the first option on the list, thus hitting down may take me to something else. However, I can't just type what I want then hit enter, hoping Firefox will take me to what I want, as Firefox seems to prioritise the homepage of the website I want over the most visited webpage of the website I want.        Long story short, whilst I could easily visit multiple webpages with little thought or effort, I now have to consciously check whether the page I want is the first or second choice on the list. This is not the worst design decision in the world, but it's hard to envision how this new system actively improves anything, whilst actively making things worse for myself, as well as probably many other users.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Dear Firefox,        You're making me pretty sad lately. I use you because as a free, open source software, I hope that your mission will keep you dedicated to serving the end user. But lately, you're doing stuff that I'm not asking you to do and making my life difficult.         I don't like opening my browser to discover the latest automatic update has disabled my favorite add-ons. That's not cool. I use those for important functions and now you're telling me I have to go deep into the configuration settings to undo this? That's really not user friendly at all.        And then you're doing this thing where you're putting ads for your own product INSIDE YOUR PRODUCT. That's super not cool. I can't see ads. It's not just that I don't like them, I have ADHD and anxiety and my job as a researcher requires me to be able to focus deeply. Ads interrupt my work and my life so intensely that it can take me days to recover from their effects. I have no facebook, no tv, no twitter, no newsfeeds, all of this because ads are such a huge problem for me. So why is my browser forcing me to see ads for itself? That is super uncool on an unfathomable level.        I really hoped that you might be immune to the corporate nonsense that makes chrome, safari and whatever browser windows is tooting right now so maddeningly frustrating to use, but lately you're going in their direction. You're basically making your product a heavier, slower version of chrome without the immediate smartphone compatibility. Why would you do that?        Please stop letting me down. Please remember your roots and bring your product back to the amazing thing it was ten years ago, or maybe even just three years ago. But whatever you do, please stop getting unawesome like you're doing now.        Thanks        (me)

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Stop messing around with the damn search engine. You're making it worse, not better. In the past, I could click on an alternate search engine, highlight the words I want to search for, right-click and search. This can be done entirely with a mouse. It's much easier than copy and paste. Now though if I click on an alternate search engine, I get automatically taken to the home page of that search engine. How ridiculously stupid is that? When we click to change the search engine, we are not asking to for a damn shortcut to the home page of that search engine. Is it that difficult to understand that some people prefer to change the search engine before they highlight the words they want to search? Sure, we can click twice to change the default search engine when one click previously suffice but we still can't even see which search engine is active as there's only a magnifying glass with the word search displayed. If it wasn't for the live RSS bookmarks, I'd switch to another browser but as it is, I'm now forced to roll back to a previous version of firefox. Stop trying to dumb down your feature rich desktop browsers into simple smartphone browsers. You're just chasing your users away.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Even though I prefer to use firefox for various reasons (better and more add-ons, better bookmarks management, etc), it does annoy me that the new 43.0.1 update has killed my Kaspersky Total Security add-ons.        I've just recently dumped AVAST Anti-Virus in favor of Kaspersky because Kaspersky provides better security and overall system performance. The various add-ons that it provides ("Dangerous Websites Blocker", "Password Manager", "Safe Money" and "Virtual Keyboard") worked properly and as intended.        However, when I upgraded Firefox this morning to 43.0.1, all Kaspersky add-ons have for some reason been disabled, with absolutely no way way of turning them back on again or finding proper updates.        Why is this? Surely Firefox has open communication channels with the major security providers (Kaspersky, Bit Defender, McAfee and Panda) in order to ensure that any add-ons provided by those products are compatible with any updates produced by Firefox?        It is very annoying that after years of using Firefox and Avast, and then switching to an alternate security product, Firefox does an about-face and tells me I can't use Kaspersky as intended.        Or should I also stop using Firefox?

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.2; Win64; x64; rv:46.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/46.0
description: Goodbye for now multi-process... :((         I have not had a whole lot of problems with the e10 enabled ever since its inception.  Every so often a page here or there would not load , but nothing that did not make sense .  But , I am disabling it for now ; and here are the main reasons:        1. It ... Is ... S... L ... O ... W ...  Seriously. Really slow.  Slower than my prepaid cell on 3G , and it is JUST Nightly . I had to do something I have not done in years in order to do my holiday shopping...  USE IE !!!  It was pure horror show (does MS NOT have a UI team ??? lol :)) , but at least it worked properly ; sadly also proving that it was again Nightly , and not the huge amount of Black Friday and Cyber Monday traffic .  Sigh .          2. Add to that the session crashes often after a slow spell ( it got to the point where I could accurately say , " This is gonna be a crash. "  And lately the crash bug submit box has not been popping up afterward every time.  That's when I know I have to 'shutdown -f -r now' enter... Dammit.  Up back back back -t 1 enter . Sigh.  Just can't bring myself to Win+D Alt+F4 R Enter lol :))    NOTE: I know the system instability after such a crash is the 'Windows Feature' of poor memory management.  Suddenly Nightly and resulting calls and sockets and paged and non paged memory go *poof* and so a couple svchost go belly up and have to reload, then time out and do the same... *bigger sigh* ... I have been dealing with THAT for three decades of professional IT experience lol :))        3. And finally , because disabling e10 has solved the issues , ( Dunno why I didn't think of that before...  Oh yeah... I always start troubleshooting at the wrong end... " DD Marcus at the Cleveland office can't get his email . "    " OK. I'm gonna check our routing tables here real quick . You go pull up his latest image off the server and have someone get me Erik at Level 3 "     " Hey sally said he just called back and said the thing that looks like a big phone cord wasn't plugged in . "  :)) ) ,     I can stop doing all kinds of tests ... stuff ... things , and worry about that next year lol :))        Happy Holiday of your choice or not choice or whatever lol :))        Cheers all !!!  Hope this made someone laugh :))

description: Just a comment about an ad for Firefox.....'The world was built by hand'..  Really? And... 'There is still nothing more powerful than  the human hand.'  Debatable at least!        Given that Firefox plays an important part in the web it would be nice to see a little humility, and maybe -  especially at Christmas -  some small acknowledgement that the web/Firefox is actually not 'the world'!  The web is simply an expression of the world which can be used for good or evil.           You tell us that the world was created by human hand'.  This again is debatable, and may be perceived as soulless, cynical arrogant and naive.        Also, whilst most people would naturally endorse your espousal of freedom,  you might also acknowledge that the  'secrecy' you associate with freedom can never be an essential part of it.  Secrecy is self-evidently not always healthy or positive;  at its extreme it can be sinister and dangerous.         Anyway, just saying.....wishing you a happy and peaceful Christmas. x

description: Ok so usually when I type the first letter of some website in the search bar it takes me to my most searched thing, but now it doesn't. I gather that that's what this new 'Visit website.com' thing is SUPPOSED to do when you type the first letter of something into the search bar, but that's not what's happened with me.         If I type a character's name into my search bar, it used to take me to their tumblr tag, no fuss. But now it takes me to RP blogs that I clicked on maybe once that have the same name as that character instead, so there's something off with whatever you use to calculate how often I use that tag.     Or, if I go to my preferred fanfiction site, instead of the first result being the character language and pairings settings that I've used without issue prior, it offers me the main website itself which is not what I want. Again, I've visited the link that has the preferred filters WAY more than the main website link itself. I'm already using that website and I don't need to be reminded of the main page.          It's a small thing but it's fucking annoying, which makes it the worst thing ever by default and a terrible feature that makes me want to switch browsers entirely. I want to disable it so how do I go about doing so?         This has nothing to do with suggested tiles by the way so don't mention them if you get back to me. I've disabled those no problem, so I don't see why it's impossible for me to disable this too.

description: Is that normal?        "This Connection is Untrusted        You have asked Firefox to connect securely to fhr.cdn.mozilla.net, but we can't confirm that your connection is secure.        Normally, when you try to connect securely, sites will present trusted identification to prove that you are going to the right place. However, this site's identity can't be verified.    What Should I Do?        If you usually connect to this site without problems, this error could mean that someone is trying to impersonate the site, and you shouldn't continue.        This site uses HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to specify that Firefox only connect to it securely. As a result, it is not possible to add an exception for this certificate.        fhr.cdn.mozilla.net uses an invalid security certificate.        The certificate is not trusted because the issuer certificate is unknown.    The server might not be sending the appropriate intermediate certificates.    An additional root certificate may need to be imported.        (Error code: sec_error_unknown_issuer)"

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Hey fffolk : )    Firstly, thank you for your work.    Secondly, I take the time and share my expertise as a former sw and UI/UX developer and sr product manager for a number of global bluechip sw companies ( in hopes that will help folks to value these insights accordingly ).    – Please place some means of providing feedback prominently and ubiquitously in the interface.    As is I had to hunt for this channel which seems probably not ideal from either your perspective nor mine.    – When upgrading please do it in such a way you provide the report on what plugins and extensions won't work BEFORE the upgrade, not after.  FF is the core solution of what we all love, but without certain extensions and plugins? It ceases to be the solution I need to do my work.  So upgrading only to find a key component missing is like upgrading your car only to find all the seats have been taken out. Sure it still runs and maybe even faster and better! But there's now a reason it's no longer the vehicle it was pre-upgrade.  So let us know the seats will be lost when we upgrade, eh?    That'll do for now.  Overall, love your work; love your ethos and this community.  For all you do… thank you.    The time and expertise spent in sharing this is my gift back to you and all of us.    Happy Holidays! º<§:º{)§

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: First off, I want to start with the fact that firefox is great, good job everyone! Now on to the sad face: I updated firefox to 43.0.1 and wanted to express my disappointment with the change to the search bar. Being able to easily select and switch to different "default" search engines was extremely helpful (selecting a different site from the dropdown menu that would remain until I selected a new one), specifically so that I could right-click on highlighted text and search from the current "default" search engine. This was efficient and helpful and I used this all day, every day! Now, I have to either drag and drop/copy paste something into the box and select which site I would like, reset the "default" within the "Change Search Settings" with each search, or just deal with it and go through google or whatever to select, say, the wikipedia or youtube result I want. I can't figure out how this change makes anything better. It does not seem to be a step forward, but a loss of functionality and efficiency and it makes me sad.
