description: The recent update putting that suggestion/search in the address bar is obnoxious in that it can't be removed. We're unable to remove every search engine, so now every time I type something in, the top two suggestions are exactly the same. I can either turn everything off when I type something into the address bar, which is not the solution I'm looking for, or I can't turn the suggestions and searches off. Why would I need two suggestions beneath the address bar, especially if 99% of the time they are the exact same thing, and more importantly, why would we not be given the ability to turn this off? If I type n into the address bar, the top two things are now "visit netflix.com" and "netflix.com" which is a whole bunch of useless. If i hit delete to remove the first "visit netflix.com" it becomes replaced with "search for n" which is again useless as I have the search bar right next to the address bar. This wouldn't be so annoying if I wasn't already used to which things came up in my history and would occasionally be hitting the second or third option down, which is now shifted away from where it used to be. It also wouldn't be so annoying if we had the ability to turn it off. What gives?

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Infinite scrolling pages are becoming increasingly common, where scrolling to the bottom of the page causes additional content to load. These pages make the scrollbar extremely difficult to use, because as soon as the content loads, the scrollbar reloads. If you are in the midst of scrolling, this triggers a scroll event and you jump to a new point on the page at the same proportional location. E.g. if you were 80% of the way down in the original content, now you are well into the new content, and need to find your place again.        Better behavior would be to wait on rescaling the scroll bar until the user releases the mouse button. Then you would never lose your place.        Of course this doesn't happen with scroll wheels, but it's a significant annoyance if you are not using one (e.g. using a pen for ergonomic reasons).

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.9; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: The search box used to provide a nice alphabetized list of the search engines I've added.        I use 2 Google image searches (1 basic, 1 for icon sized images).  I also have two "Alternative To" searches (1 basic, 1 for free or open source).  So now I have two identical icons for Google Image search and two for Alternative To, which I can't tell apart unless I stop and mouse over each of them and wait for the text to appear.  Previously, it was immediately obvious which was which.        Depending on which OS I'm using, the following allowed me to to switch search engines within seconds:         command/control-L         tab         option/alt-down_arrow         (the first letter of the search engine)        So on OSX, command-l, tab, option-down, "g" would select google... "i" would select IMDB.        This is now broken, replaced by something MUCH slower, which requires more thought and effort.        Honestly, I understand that most users are clueless and I understand some might need "training wheels".  But while training wheels may be appropriate for beginners, with bicycles they are easily removed when they're no longer needed or appropriate.  The equivalent should apply here.        Just to be clear, I really HATE this change.  And while I now recall something about some tweak related to localization or something, I'm annoyed that I have to keep fixing this crap whenever a new update comes out and breaks things.        Honestly, I do appreciate all the work that the developers are doing.  Firefox, when extended with Tab Mix Plus, All In One Sidebar, No Script, and Flashblock still provides me the most compelling power-user browsing experience I have found.        The problem is that over the last few years a trend in software has emerged where more and more of the software I use has been dumbed-down or changed in ways that make it less productive or completely useless to me.  When it's something as important to me as Firefox is, it touches a nerve.

description: I I have been using an add on called plainoldfavorites.  It stopped working today because it could not be verified. description: To whom it may concern,      Before purchasing my new desktop I worked in XP pro and loved it and did not want to change my operating system.     But the pressure from Microsoft to change-up was enormous, especially with Microsoft sabotaging the software support market for XP. I would like to note that the only one supporting XP was Firefox that allowed me to quickly browse where Microsoft Explorer did not (slow and unresponsive).       Therefore, I now own one of the latest computers: I7 Intel Processor 6th Generation Quad Core 64Bit, etc. and I am Firefox loyal and have set it as my default browser. It has always been quick to launch and incredibly reliable but of late it seems to hang and has radically slowed down in performance. It seems as if I'm always waiting for it to load    or perform the next function. At this point I would like to reiterate that it has never done this previously on my new computer system.     I should also inform you that I have done the latest update and I am using "43.0.1"  and I also have on my computer system Microsoft Edge for Windows 10. I have recently launched "Edge" to see if there is any problem with it as far as hanging and being unresponsive at times, and instead it is quick and immediately very responsive. However, I hate the format and dislike using it, due to my aversion of anything Microsoft. I prefer to use "Firefox," but its performance, as I have previously stated, is beginning to become frustrating: It seems comparatively speaking to previous performance to be hanging, slow and unresponsive.  I would like you if you can to remedy this and I really want to continue to use  "Firefox" as my default browser!    I would also like to state for the record that I'm not a "paranoid" person but I wouldn't be surprised if in some way Microsoft has figured out a way through Microsoft 10 to create an incompatibility with "Firefox" which acts to create    a hanging, slowing, and unresponsiveness.  Please help me!!!        Cheers        Steve

description: Actually sad is a extremely bad description, so that should be fixed. I'm angry and frustrated because the Preferences have become damn near impossible to use as a result of them being confined to tabs. I can't find what I need anymore, the additional tab clutters on the browser so it becomes damn near useless sometimes when I'm using it, and every time I close it and reopen it, I ave to hunt for the setting I need all over again.         None of this was never a problem was ever a problem before you took away the ability to open the preferences as a separate window. You took the only browser I could use and turned it into something as utterly useless as every other browser out there, only for different reasons. You have turned Firefox into yet another hated piece of software, one I only use because I have no other choice, not one I use because I want to.        Let's face it. You've broken the only good browser. You've destroyed the only good browser. Mozilla's no better than Microsoft: you can't help making things worse with each new release.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Since the latest update on mac, double clicking on the tab bar now minimises the window, rather than opening a new tab. I find this highly annoying. I understand that the tab bar has been combined with the title bar, but I never use the double click title bar method to minimise, and I keep minimising when I want a new tab. It would be great if a preference could be added to choose which behaviour is preferred.        Given that both new tab and minimise have dedicate buttons on the left of the screen, it makes sense to use this shortcut for whichever you use most often. For me I use new tab two orders of magnitude more often than minimise.

description: Please stop changing the search bar!  It is, without a doubt, what originally influenced me and likely thousands of other users to switch from other browsers. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I just upgraded Firefox and it broke my Search settings.        When a previous Firefox upgrade started displaying search engine icons at the bottom of the Search suggestions list, it was distracting as hell, so I turned it off.        Now I'm told that I CAN'T turn it off (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1099665), and I absolutely HATE that!        The LAST thing I want when I'm in the middle of searching is a distraction.        The previous search functionality hid search engine options under a down immediately right of the Q in the search bar. I could easily switch search engines, but unless I clicked the bar to display that drop-down list, there was no visual distraction.        Now even if I deselect all alternate search engines in order to hide the distracting colored icons, thus destroying my ability to easily switch between search engines, I STILL see my selected search engine's distracting colored icon in the drop-down when I start a search, along with a Change Search Settings menu items. This sucks!        Folks, when I do a search I am SEARCHING. I want my attention focused ON MY SEARCH. I want to experience zip, zero, no distractions FROM my search. No visual distractions, no drop-down menu items, NOTHING BUT MY SEARCH (plus search suggestions, but only if I asked for them). And I want this in monochrome, so the color doesn't distract me. (Remember, some people are much more visually distractable than others.)        Please, PLEASE restore the old search functionality as an option ASAP. And ideally make it so that those of us who had our preferences set to hide the newer Search functionality get the new search functionality replaced by the old again.        Thank you,    a usually very happy Firefox user    who is off to install Classic Theme Restorer so I can get back to *using my freaking browser*.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: As a very long time Firefox user and supporter, I've got to object vociferously to Mozilla's plans eliminate the override of enforcing add-on signing beginning with Firefox version 44. I realize that it may very well be prudent to require add-no signing for Firefox users who are not adept at computers. But Mozilla would be very wise to continue to allow experienced users to override enforcement of add-on signing. Enforcing signing would kill off 10 add-ons that make my Firefox experience more efficient and pleasurable. Even the Adobe Acrobat DC add-on does not pass the signing test. Classic Theme Restorer also fails -- and without those two I will have to discontinue using Firefox. I vastly prefer Firefox and recommend Firefox to all my clients for whom I build computers.        Given that Firefox usage continues to slide, I would like to suggest that the decision to eliminate the override of add-on signing will only cost Mozilla more Firefox users. I strongly urge you to allow the override to continue indefinitely so that experienced Firefox users can continue to use the add-ons that make Firefox their browser of choice.        Thank you for your time and consideration.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: Downgraded after I found the most recent update removed the clickable search icon from the search bar. It was a needless change (not like we needed those 25 pixels more in the search bar itself, which is already, what, 350 pixels long?) To do the same thing now, I either have to click on the text area of the search bar itself, then press enter, or click on the drop-down arrow (which now highlights if I can add a new search engine based on the page selected), and click on Google (my preferred search engine). I know removing features is usually to streamline things, but to me, this is removing the most streamlined feature, in favour of promoting a more complex feature I simply have no need of. If I wanted to add a new search engine, I would click "customize" or "manage search engines". On my main window screen, I really only need access to the features which I make active use of. If my search bar is on my toolbar, it's because I want to use it regularly, and not see it removed by updates without even a customization feature that allows me to bring it back.         I believe I may have used "browser.search.showOneOffButtons" in previous versions to get the searchbar to my liking, but this option no longer resolves the issue, so I hope you will bring it back for future updates.

To change active engine I now have to open the options menu for every new sequence of searches or to click the magnifying glass and then choose the engine, now from unnamed icons complicating things further with sites with similar icons (e.g. Wikipedia in different languages), for every new search, instead of just pressing enter (already have the fingers on the keyboard). As it stands the searchbar is so useless to me that it is quicker to just load the relevant site, completely negating the point of the searchbar. This is of course fine as this version probably is useful for a lot of people, but why remove the support for "browser.search.showOneOffButtons", or is that a bug in version 43 (WinXP)? I could just set that to "false" to get the version useful to me, but this no longer works. As a person who does a lot of research on the Internet this is an important function to me that just ceased to work. If it clutters the code, perhaps you could release optional modules. In wait for a functional searchbar I go back to version 42 to get the search feature back. I really need it!    Apart from that, thanks for the great work! You all have made a great program. I feel I should add that. It is a massive feat!

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Dear Firefox team,        The old search bar is now completely gone, and I really miss it. Now even the browser.search.showOneOffButtons config doesn't help to restore the old search bar.        I have lots of custom search engines configured in my search bar, and I tend to do many searches at once in a single search engine. Usually I could just select the preferred search engine once, then whenever I need to search, I can Ctrl+T for a new tab, then Ctrl+E into my search bar, type a thing, and hit Return. Now I need to use a mouse click once per search, and it is very annoying and disrupts my workflow.        Also note that some of the sites I need to search in don't have favicons, and the new search interface no longer shows the name of the site. The search options are therefore literally indistinguishable without hovering over them, and that's incredibly annoying, at least for me.        Dear Firefox team, please please bring the old search functionality back. It doesn't have to be by default, but it should at least be available as a settings option, and this option should be more accessible than in about:config.        [In general, please don't just remove features without a very good reason. If you replace them with new features, please add a settings option that lets you revert to the old features.]        Thank you very much for your attention,    -Me

description: i did a little comparison of opening facebook videos in a new tab and watching it in my pinned facebook tab. if i open in a new tab, watch it and close it, memory usage goes back down to its original value. if i watch it in my pinned tab, memory usage doesn't go back down to its original value as quickly. not sure if it's a memory leak or if it just takes longer to go back to original. well it's not as bad as it used to be for the last 2-3 firefox releases where i had to restart firefox so often due to opening facebook videos and memory usage getting stuck at 1.5 gib sometimes if i watched too many, even after closing the videos. now it's at 560 mib which is a great improvement ! thanks :)

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Very disappointed that you are refusing to let me keep old unsigned addons that I've used for a long time. I know installing new unknown software can be dangerous, but I've used the same addons for a while now and I don't plan to install more. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: After setting up firefox on my Macbook 12" Retina, I have had difficulty connecting to several sites that are critical to me.  Initially, the problem was the Agilebits site, as I am a 1Password user and always install the 1Password Firefox extension.  For quite awhile I would not be able to connect with the site, and would get this notice:  "Secure Connection Failed - An error occurred during a connection to sslvpn.wyle.com. Peer's certificate has an invalid signature. (Error code: sec_error_bad_signature) The page you are trying to view cannot be shown because the authenticity of the received data could not be verified. Please contact the website owners to inform them of this problem."  (Contacting the website owners is basically a non-starter.)  I use Avast Mac Security, and found the I could only connect if I completely turn off the Web shields.  Finally, I found I was able to keep the Web Shields on, but turn off "Scan Secured Connections" within the Web shields settings.  Now, even with that setting on Avast, I am unable to connect with the SSL VPN site of my company (address below).  Before you go telling me to take my complaint to Avast (I'm doing that as well), you should know that the issue is completely unique to Firefox.  I've had no such problems with either Safari or Chrome, and I use the Avast extension with both of them.  So I'm inclined to assign the lion's share of the problem to Firefox.  I do not want to quit using Firefox (I've been using it on both mac and Windows for more than 10, and probably more like 15 years), but at the moment, due to the above problem, I have (sadly) quit using it.  Please help me solve this problem.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I have developed and use several XUL extensions such as a mainframe terminal emulator and a mainframe report endpoint and dynamic XUL presentations in lieu of PowerPoint.  Some of them are are signed using McCoy, since they use the Automatic Update feature. I do not want to be required to submit these extensions to Mozilla for signing, as they are essentially for private use. If the current plan proceeds, then Version 43 with signing disabled will most likely be my last Firefox release version. I will initially switch to the Firefox Developer Edition, and I will advise my users to do the same, and if that is impractical, I will probably switch to Chrome. I think this policy will sound the death knell for FireFox, which makes me extremely sad and disappointed. If you try and make Firefox similar to Chrome, then people will use Chrome. Let the user of Firefox decide whether or not they trust an extension which they are thinking about installing, maybe by warning of any dangerous constructs.

description: When typing urls into the address bar, the visit "suggestion"/search with google box is just in the way.The main problem I have is that it is taking up the first slot result. It is the first thing I see and it is useless information, I'm looking for a specific url and a suggestion to visit something else or do a random search is not what I need. I'm sure on the firefox end it provides a useful Ad or tracking search but for my usage it is just doubling results. Why bother displaying visit google.com and right below it www.google.com. It is an eyesore and annoying enough that I am considering not using firefox anymore. If I wanted to search for something, I could just use keyword search and type it in and hit enter, why would I select the visit result or search result with a mouse? I am mostly frustrated with it cluttering the actual results I'm looking for and not having an option to turn it off is aggravating. I'm sure there must be some design philosophy reason for implementing it, but at least allow the option to toggle it. Maybe consider moving it to the bottom of the results or somewhere else.

description: As a user I want to wipe all local data that is related to the current page (domain).        WHEN I choose to forget the current page    THEN Firefox shall discard (close) the current page (Tab) without triggering any event in that page's context (e.g. JS)    AND Firefox shall remove all cookies and history related to that page (domain).        * This feature could be accessed from the "Forget about some some browsing history" or from the page info. "Wipe page" came to my mind as a command name.    * This feature shall take the idea of forgetting from a time-based approach to a location-based one. It can be compared to resetting the page info counters (and taking care that the open page has no chance to score right after that).        I was prepared to write a feature request in Bugzilla, but the issue creating dialog took me to this feedback form. I hope this is the right place to drop the idea.

Practically impossible to use the Bookmarks Toolbar anymore !!!!!    Please put it back like it was in version 42!        2) PAGE BOOKMARKED    Since a long time it is bad and is still: the "Page Bookmarked" window to save a bookmarks is such a un-handy thing. (still this version only copies the URLs),    – to copy a selected folder including its content from the Library sidebar (inc. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I used to really enjoy the dropdown list of search-providers by editing about:config, and setting browser.search.showOneOffButtons to false.        Now, Firefox has updated itself, and this functionality is lost. Instead, I have a very user-unfriendly grid of squares, and if I want to search via an alternative search provider, I have to make a search with the initial provider, then repeat the search with the new provider by clicking one of the squares, thus doubling my workflow.        I am glad that I can restore this functionality with the 'Classic Theme Restorer' add-on, but I would ask you, pretty please, that in future versions of Firefox, you let your Users chose how they wish to configure the browser instead of just taking things away from them without warning. Happy Christmas!!

description: 1) I would like to state that the new search-bar UI is terrible -- far less versatile and intuitive than the old one. Yes, I know that this might be considered 'old news' but, like many others, I simply found the preference to turn it off and happily went on my way, until you nuked it entirely in the latest version.        2) Not giving any indication that this preference was only temporary (and that the old UI would be done away with entirely) was a really terrible idea. It simply delayed the feedback until you did away with the temporary preference (and in this case the old UI), leading to large numbers of complaints and requests to add back in functionality that the old UI already contained.        3) In light of this, I'd also like to say that I consider your new "visit" enhancement to the URL bar to be annoying and counter-productive. Needless to say, I very quickly went in search of the preference to remove it. PLEASE DO NOT LIKEWISE REMOVE THIS PREFERENCE!

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: i had some youtube videos open but memory usage was high so i restarted firefox. then i started opening links from my pinned facebook tab. i restarted to check memory usage but messed up by opening more links. so i clicked close on firefox and the menu bar appeared as it has been sometimes with this version when i click close. i right clicked the menu bar area and it showed menu bar not ticked so that must be a bug. then firefox would not close and i did not get the prompt to wait or kill firefox process. system monitor showed firefox at 100% cpu for one of my threads/cores. i have dual core cpu but 4 threads i think called cpu1, 2, 3 and 4. so the 100% kept moving to different cpus there. i ended the firefox process. when i restarted firefox i got a blank tab and my tab groups gone! luckily i knew to click history and restore window and got my tabs back. sad to see this happen. i think it would be helpful if firefox was able to detect this and offer restoring a window so it's not lost forever in that history button in the menu. some people might not think to go there and end up trying to recover profiles etc. firefox should detect a user's habits and notice that, oh, this time firefox was started but only 1 new tab, when previously it was 4 pinned tabs and lots of background tabs. then realise there's also a window that can be restored with that previous session and offer this to the user so there's less confusion and no need to search in the menu for the recovery option. hope this makes sense and you can add this kind of feature. thanks !

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.9; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I've complained about the "new" search bar in the past. Until now, there has been a simple method to return to the older style search bar, but with Firefox 43, this method no longer works.        See this article for more details:    http://www.ghacks.net/2015/12/16/how-to-restore-classic-search-in-firefox-43/        As noted in the article, it is possible to use the "Classic Theme Restorer" add-on to bring back the old search interface, but this is not an ideal solution. Firefox needs to provide a solution that allows users to search the web quickly and securely.        The new search bar has two major problems:        * Searching requires unnecessary page loads. The user enters their search term, Firefox submits it to the default search provider (not the one the user wants!), then the user selects the search provider, and the search is performed again. This is a waste of time and bandwidth.        * There is a potential breach of privacy. Since the current search engine is not displayed until after the search is initiated, if a user is searching for a sensitive topic, their search term may be sent somewhere they did not intend it to go.        The old-style search was a perfect solution, and it was the main reason I used Firefox as my preferred browser for so long. I'm not completely against change, but the new search interface is just broken. I will use "Classic Theme Restorer" add-on for now, but I really hope someone at Firefox takes note of these problems, and initiates an effort to fix them.

description: For the past 10 days (start Dec 10) Yahoo mail has been slow, showing the buffering circle, for as much as 20 seconds, when I click on a message, then often returning: "unable to load message" "taking longer than usual to load message", "unable to load message list" "try again". While microsoft's new edge browser is returning the same "delays", it is not taking nearly as long or returning delay messages nearly as often as Firefox.     I do Not have any (additional delays that are noticeable) noticeable delays on mail from my ISP or live.com mail.        I usually remove half, or more, of my cookies, daily, using your privacy option, then close Firefox. I have been running CCleaner afterwards, and many of the same cookies I have just deleted show as present in CCleaner. The same was true with FF 41 and 42. Do you have any explanation??    I keep the cookies for about 4-5 sites that I don't want to log into, again, or reset my preferences, and delete the rest.    I open your options (it opens a new tab). user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: The only suggestion that I have to improve Firefox is to make the Bookmarks work like other browsers. If I right click and delete an unwanted bookmark, it shows back up again. Firefox keeps re-organizing my bookmarks in alphabetical order. I don't want this unless I select "Sort by Name". If I save a new bookmark, it doesn't show up. Only in "recently added". Make the bookmarks work as they do in IE or Chrome. There is too much work involved to manage bookmarks. Bookmarks have an icon associated with them that get deleted when I re-boot my computer.    I had to disable an Ad-On because it drastically slowed the browser as if it was tracking me and sending out my browsing history to millions of un-named 3rd parties.    Firefox blocks images in some of my emails. I have to use the dreaded IE to see what Ebay has suggested for me.    Otherwise, I love it. It is very fast. Web pages don't load at dial-up speeds anymore. I don't get error messages asking me to stop slow running Java Scripts. The scroll bars are never locked until ads & videos are completely loaded first before any content of interest. The tabs and browser can be closed at any time. They aren't hijacked & disabled by rouge websites. I don't have to open Task Manager anymore to force the browser to close and get logged out of any site that I was visiting because my browser was allowed to be taken over by a website. I don't see ads related to my browsing history from other sites while browsing IN PRIVATE as was the case with the new Edge browser. Opening another tab does not disable all other tabs until all advertisements & videos are loaded first, or locks up as with Edge. Edge has little support to view PDF documents. It is the biggest piece of spyware on the planet next to Windows 10. Chrome was faster, but shared some of the same problems as IE. I don't like logging in to Google to get access to my bookmarks. They can better track you that way. I don't get 199 tracking cookies for my Internet Eraser to delete when I close the browser. It took about 3 days of use before I made Firefox my default browser. Yahoo locked up all of the time and is extremely slow with all of the flash ads and videos it downloads as top priority over content. Now, Yahoo is fast when using Firefox. You don't use up you bandwidth limits for the month viewing just one website anymore. The ads are still visible too. The browser is responsive and doesn't slow or lock up like Edge or IE. I give Firefox a 5 star rating. If they simplify the bookmark management, I'll give it 6 to 7 stars out of a maximum of 5 stars.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I have been a loyal Firefox user and have been generally satisfied with changes and improvements. However, the forced addition of the "Search With" line to the Awesome Location Bar is the only change you've ever made that I really, really hate. I mean, hate. Like, "Switch-browsers-and-block-Mozilla.org-on-my-firewall" kinda hate. I like being able to type a few letters and hit down arrow and enter, secure in the comfortable knowledge that Firefox will take me to all the best places that we've always enjoyed together. Now, I type "ord" and hit down arrow and then enter, and rather then my favorite online food-ordering establishment, I get a lousy search page with the top result of Chicago O'Hare International Airport. I live in Colorado, I don't need an airport page to order food! But your new, awful, "Search With" autopopulating waste of electrons has made years (hell, pretty much a decade) of muscle memory useless and annoying. I don't use products that make an integral part of me useless and annoying. Thankfully, after much more searching than I should have had to do, I found a developer article on setting browser.urlbar.unifiedcomplete to false. Once I did this, the Firefox I know and love returned to me and we joined hands and skipped happily to all the open and joyous fields the internet has to provide. If you are going to change something an integral as how the location bar works with an annoying and truly awful feature, please make the ability to turn is off explicit somewhere in preferences. For everyone one person like myself that is set in their ways enough to hate this and yet  saavy enough to fix it, there are likely thousands who will just switch browsers rather than be annoyed, dig for hours to fix it and then write pissy feedback.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: There appears to be a security breach with Firefox data being accessible by other browsers, namely SafeZone from AVAST. If I am logged into Yahoo or Facebook in Firefox and go to SafeZone, I can view my Yahoo mail and my Facebook page without logging in. Not the case in IE or Safari in that neither of these browsers can display the pages without logging in first. In fact they display the login pages. Firefox is my default browser and I have not tried to set IE as the default to see if things change. This is a severe breach of security since another address space should not be able to access Firefox data and sessions.        Please advise if there is some Firefox setting I can use to stop this cross program data sharing. My preference would be to lock up the session data so another program can't find it. Don't know if this has to do with cookies, local storage, or what, but I am concerned. Avast may be trustworthy but the next guy won't be. Seems to me this could happen in the background and one would never know what Yahoo emails would be sent or Facebook postings made.

description: Security issue on clicking 'Restore session' button - When i close the session directly from the browser, all the logged in sessions will be automatically logged out. The next time you visit that webpage you will have to enter your credentials again to log in. But with the new 'Restore previous session' button, all the pages that i had logged in will be opened and will be in logged in state. This is a major security flaw. What if someone else is using my pc after i close firefox? i would be under the impression that all the logged in websites have been logged out, but if the person clicks on the Restore button, all the websites will be logged in again. Please look into this issue.     This issue happens on all major webpages like gmail.com, facebook.com, youtube.com    Thanks.

description: multiple tabs.    Just wanted to give you an idea: when pressing the "open in a new tab" button the new tab should open on the left side of the original tab. Why this? because whenever you close the newly opened tab, the one on the right of it opens although we might not need it for the moment.     If the new tab opens in the left of the original one, whenever you close it it takes you back to the original one, not loading a new one.    Cheers , Mike

description: This is what comes up when i try to access Facebook:        This Connection is Untrusted        You have asked Firefox to connect securely to www.facebook.com, but we can't confirm that your connection is secure.        Normally, when you try to connect securely, sites will present trusted identification to prove that you are going to the right place. However, this site's identity can't be verified. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I like Firefox and it is my primary browser and my default home page. I bounce around a couple different laptops and love the fact my bookmarks on one are available on the other. How convenient for me. Hooray.        I enjoy Firefox enough so that when your messages started cropping asking for support, I went ahead and made a donation.         A thus the cause of my frowny face.         You would think people who designed such a useful browser that can do your bookmark update voodoo across multiple devices might enable some system to track those who supported your fundraising efforts.         It would be stellar if when logging in to my pc and firing my browser up, when landing on my homepage instead of being hit up again for more money, it simply said "Hey, thank you for your support."         Maybe even further you could adjust it so at the 1, 3, 6, and 12 month marks it thanked you again and asked if you would be interested in making an additional donation. And set it up to be ticked "off" if user is not interested in renewing at the 1/3/6/12 month marks... so they don't get ticked off constantly being asked to donate after having already done so.         Thanking and acknowledging donors is a great way to influence them to donate again.Bombarding them with continued asks after having already donated might have the opposite effect.        My $10 donation surely doesn't merit a ticker tape parade and first class plane tickets to Mozilla HQ for a tour of your offices, but it would be swell if I got a "Thanks, amigo, we appreciate your support. You are a hoopy frood." message on logging instead of more "donate" asks as if I never gave in the first place.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: (English isn't my mother tongue)        I'm specifically not much interested in customizing every aspect of the browser and I'm okay with how it's working as of now, but I still don't think that the way your browser is evolving in right now has light at the end of the tunnel.        In the days before Opera 13, I used to browse with only that browser.    It was very convenient.    It had tons of configuration settings and it was very customizable.    Although it used a layout engine which wasn't very popular and supported (Presto), it worked.    And it worked very well.        And then came Opera 13, which was based on Chromium; EVERYTHING good about that browser had lost.        I plan to start using Vivaldi browser when it will finally be released, but I'm afraid I'll lose the potential of the Firefox add-ons (as I said, I don't use any fancy customization and as of writing the only add-on I have installed is AdBlock Plus, but it's never too late).        Vivaldi is based on Chromium and it means one thing: it's depending on Google.        WebExtensions is a good idea of implementing a more modern extensions API, but it also means becoming more like Google Chrome; I fear that when the time will come, Firefox will lose many of it's add-ons API features and things that were possible with the previous system will not be possible any more.        Please focus your resources on making the best add-ons API you can make, greatly improving Project Electrolysis, improving Web standards support, making optimizations but most importantly:    Making the browser more customizable and appealing for power-users.    If you'll do that, I am certainly sure Firefox' market share will GREATLY INCREASE, and Mozilla will have a brighter future.

description: A lot of people would donate, who, like me, presently have no plan to do so, if it weren't so obvious that personal information provided to you will be used in ways that donors do not wish.  No one...NO ONE...wants to be on anyone's sucker list, soliciting donations to phony or bloated charities.  So stop pretending that you value users' privacy...or keep user information PRIVATE.  Someday, Congress will finally pass laws prohibiting use of private information acquired by websites, which would put dangerous data thieves like Facebook, who prey on innocent, lonely people, out of business.  Does Mozilla want to join them?  No?  Then do something to KEEP PERSONAL INFORMATION PRIVATE.  Checking off the box that says a donor agrees with your privacy policy won't do it.  You have no effective privacy policy, so don't hypocritically suggest that you're "special."  You aren't.  No, I won't donate, even if you go out of business...until you solve this problem and widely publish this change...which you promise to make permanent. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Mozilla has finally done it.        I have used Firefox for ten years. I have strongly advocated and evangelized Firefox within my circles.        And now I just can't do it anymore. Mozilla has, to all appearances, become an organization dedicated to political causes and removing any feature from Firefox that makes it unique, whether it be Panorama or the extension API, or any other of the million things somebody, somewhere at Mozilla HQ arbitrarily decided to remove (or in the case of e.g. Pocket, add). I can't help but wonder if Mozilla is being deliberately sabotaged by people who hate Firefox. It's becoming that awful. (You'll see my version number is 43; I was on the beta channel, and just went through an ordeal to switch back to the release channel since you geniuses decided to remove the channel switching UI.)        I've disabled automatic updates until I can decide where to go from here and I will be strongly dis-recommending Firefox.        As best I can tell, at least part of it is that Mozilla no longer cares about the power users that drove initial Firefox adoption and evangelization. But I'm sure you guys already know that.        Thanks, for making my daily web experience that much more bitter and shittier. I know I can't stay on an old Firefox version forever for security reasons and I'll eventually have to move to Edge or I suppose Chrome. And the whole time I'll be thinking "man, before they shit up Firefox, this would have been so much better."        Thanks assholes.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: This probably isn't the only complaint about the search bar change. I'll start by stating that this isn't about aversion to change. Many who frequently use the search bar will have a problem with the new search bar. The design flaw is very real; it adds to the number of necessary operations. That's a big no-no, unless the entire purpose of the product is aesthetic. I presume that isn't Mozilla's intention with Firefox.        Specifically:        Before: Put hand on mouse, click search bar, select engine, take hand off mouse, type search term, hit return.    Now: Put hand on mouse, click search bar, take hand off mouse, type search term, put hand on mouse, click search bar, select search engine.        Of these operations, the movement between keyboard and mouse is the most significant. It's also the one you have added with this change.        Making it worse:        I use many search engines, but the main predictor of my next search, is the previous search. Consequently, I want the last search engine chosen to be the default for new searches. This saved many operations on the old search bar. The new search bar makes it a clumsy procedure.        Also, among my many search engines are ones without logo, with similar logos, and with identical logos. The texted name of the engine really was necessary.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: A website called mail.com keeps taking over my home page when I open the browser.     It happens around every four weeks.    Is it possible they are piggybacking on my Firefox updates?     For example, I get a message from Mozilla, it says "Do you want to allow Mozilla to make changes to your computer?"     It offers me Firefox 43.0.1 - which then slaps the mail.com advertising as my home page.    I've disabled the add-on from mail.com, but now it appears to be masquerading as a legit message from Mozilla.    Unless, of course, you guys actually *have* an update called 43.0.1 - but I have the most current version of Firefox.        Mail.com is extremely obnoxious and has a very bad reputation for mining through all emails and contacts on whatever machine is running their program.

This has occurred on 4 of the 5 computers we have running LInuxMint 17.3.  On two of the computers I downloaded and enabled automatic updates through mozilla.org, the other two are Firefox 43 from LinuxMint.  The issue seems to be related to cookies.  We have adblock plus, ghostery and noscript as addons.    I have stopped automatic updates and stopped syncing.  I have installed Chromium on each machine.  I will attempt to download 42 and install that.  I am not a geek, so I am not super confident, but we need functionning browsers.

Frankly, I think Mozilla's association with Yahoo and it's crap search engine besmirches Mozilla's reputation. Google remains the best and Bing is the next best -- but that is beside the point. I don't understand the point of allowing for customization if the customer cannot actually customize anything. I'm sorry to no longer be able to use your software.

description: Firefox is a very fast and stable browser. It has surpassed chrome in many ways. The improvements in speed and usability has tempted me to switch to firefox from chrome. It would be a good idea to enable telemetry by default in all versions of firefox, including the stable release, across all the platforms, so that developers can get more data to the usage of the browser. Many people don't turn on telemetry, so developers never get to know what most of the users want out of the browser. It would be even better to collect more data about the usage of firefox, so that it can be improved in many ways in the future.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Why did you change the search box functionality back again? Or rather, turn off the override that allowed the old functionality? Since v34 I've used the browser.search.showOneOffButtons=true option to keep the functionality of the box. I really liked the way it worked in the past! In fact it's part of why I still use Firefox as my default browser. Normally I have the search set to Google, and I can see the Google icon there and know that when I search for something I'm going to get Google results. But if I'm wanting to buy some stuff on Amazon, I drop it down to Amazon for a while. Same for eBay or Wikipedia - I switch the box based on what I'm currently working on. Most importantly, I have the visual of the icon, so when I'm about to search for something again, I know if I need to switch it back. I can go about my business without having to stop and think about the interface. Now that the override no longer works, I basically have to stop, look and think EVERY TIME I want to do a search, because I don't necessarily remember where I left it. Sure, I can pretty easily change the default with a click, point, right-click operation (still a lot more trouble than a single click-select), but it's the "stop and think because there's no visual cue" that is really messing up my established workflow. The interface should, in my opinion, "just work" without me having to stop and think about how it's working. That leaves me more brain power for the actual task at hand (i.e. figuring out what to search for and then reviewing the results). I'm going back to v42. If I hear that this has been fixed, I'll start updating again. Thanks!        BTW, I do really like having a search box, and the fact that other browsers have gone more to "search from the URL box" is another reason I remain with Firefox. If I want to type a URL, I put it in the URL box. If I want to search, I use the search box. Maybe that's old fashioned, but I prefer to work that way.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: While I understand the reasons for the "signed add-ons" policy applied with Firefox 43.0 and appreciate the advanced notice, the reality is that disabling plug-ins that are the interface between important commercial products and Firefox is debilitating for users and getting the plug-ins signed is not really under their control.  I understand how to disable the check but being permitted (or forced) to do that only globally, rather than for one specific plug-in, is security-weakening, not security-improving, especially when the plug-in uses its own validation methods in conjunction with this base package.        This is not a theoretical issue.  I don't know about others, but the signature requirement has disabled the plug-in that allows recent commercial, "Pro", versions of Adobe Acrobat to assemble copies of web pages into PDF files.  Adobe is aware of the problem but seems to be proceeding slowly, I assume because of their own multi-platform production and commit processes.        Before they get a signed version posted, you have essentially put me -- and, I assume, a very large number of other Acrobat users -- into a position where we have little choice other than going to other browsers when we need those Acrobat services.  Of, of course, we can freeze at 42.x or earlier, but that prevents us from installing security and other upgrades to the base browser.  Neither option benefits either the user nor Mozilla.        I think Firefox is badly in need of a reasonably easy-to-use mechanism for disabling the signature requirement on a per-plug-in basis.  Put whatever warnings in front of that which you like.  Warn people about it every time Firefox is upgraded (or even started) if you think that is appropriate.  But making it impossible to use a particular plug-in that doesn't conform to your signature standards sets you up as the protocol or security police, appears to me to violate Open Source principles, and is generally unwise, especially when it seems to me that you are already walking a fine line by favoring some commercial products over others (e.g., by switching everyone to Yahoo! as the default search engine when they upgraded).        If it is of interest, the discussion of this subject on the Adobe site is at https://forums.adobe.com/message/8325306#8325306.   I don't think you need to log in to read the thread.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Mozilla has now evidently implemented digital signing for extensions, with no provision for an override in the latest version of Firefox. For those using screenreaders, there is an extension called Webvisum which assists us in solving captchas, without which we're unable to perform essential services on websites, especially those which have not implemented an audio or similar alternative. The software is not being maintained & therefore is not digitally signed. While your adherence to digital signatures is commendable, there really should be an override, as I now find myself having to revert to a previous version of Firefox in order to use this extension. Other blind people are similarly situated. So it seems like Mozilla is quite willing to compromise the security of users who need or want a particular extension as opposed to simply allowing for an override. That does not seem quite fair, & indeed, from my viewpoint, it seems to go against what Mozilla stands for. It'd be good if you'd treat your users as though they're not stupid. Let us make the decision as to whether our need or desire for a particular add-on is a security risk. Warn us--yes--but don't shove it down our throats. There are exceptions to everything, & I'd think approving an individual extension with an understanding of the risks is a far better security alternative than reverting to an old version w/updates disabled in order to be able to use the desired addon.

Taking the SAVE option sends the file off to some unknown location within my machine.  I then have to begin the arduous and infuriatingly time consuming process of looking through folder after folder to locate it.  It used to be so easy.  All I needed to do was click "SAVE AS", select the folder where I keep all downloaded apps.  But NO, you have to make it a game of hide and seek.  You must get a lot of laughs thinking about someone like me struggling with issues such as this that you've created.    Secondly, why do you insist on having this Adobe software in your browser. The only cure I am able to find for this is to do CTRL+ALT+DELETE to open the Task Manager to shut down Firefox and restart it, thus causing me to lose all the tabs I was working with.  Your browser used to be far better than any other, but it is getting to the point that I am reluctant to use it because of all these problems and others that seem to arise every time a new version of Firefox is installed. user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I am unhappy that I can no longer use the 'old' search box functionality.   For the last while the browser.search.showOneOffButtons was my answer to keep the search bar working the way I want it.          I like to be able to select which search to use and then type what I want to search for.   I can then quickly toggle to a different engine and search that one.        However the real reason why I loved the previous system was that I could select which engine to search with and then highlight some text on the page and right click and search with that selected engine.   Now I seem to be only able to search with the first engine in my list.          I've been mocked by my friends for continuing to use Firefox and I defended my preference with this feature which doesn't exist on other browsers, and I used it frequently.           The lack of continued support for the browser.search.showOneOffButtons feature will change the way I use the internet in a negative way.           I understand that extra branches in code make things more complex, but really the old way was the best way ;)

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: You changed the search to the new one-click version a while ago—up until now I was able to keep it the old way using about:config and changing browser.search.showOneOffButtons to false, but that stopped working.        The problem with the one-click search is that it makes it impossible to use search suggestions with any search engine other than the default. Did you guys think about this? If I want to search "mozilla firefox" on my default search engine, I just type "moz" and then arrow down with the arrow keys to the complete suggestion and press enter. If I want to search it on Wikipedia—first of all, there is no way to get search suggestions based on Wikipedia search if it's not the default—and second of all, I have to type the entire phrase, then click the icon. It's awkward as hell to have to type the entire thing I'm searching, and then actually have to pick up my mouse and click something when I'm done.

description: I've been using firefox for nearly a decade and have stuck with you guys all the way. I don't use chrome because I like firefox etc.. I like firefox and don't use chrome for a reason.         I have used firefox to tailor my internet browsing experience to exactly how I like it, but you guys keep taking away functionality and changing things for completely arbitrary reasons and forcing people to get addons to have the browser act as it has in previous versions. This does not make sense.         Now my current complaint, the latest update has taken away the about:config setting "showOneOffButtons" and the ability to change the search toolbar back to the old style. The new style is less user friendly for multiple reasons. With the old style I could do a bunch with the keyboard. Luckily addons like Classic Theme Restorer exist and allow me to change it back, but you've got to see how ridiculous that is, that that's necessary.         Take care of the people who are loyal to you and stop trying to win people over from chrome because it's not going to happen and all you do in attempting to do that is alienate your loyalists and push them to chrome. We don't need new functionality or huge UI changes, we're using firefox already for a reason. You're not impressing anyone with this stuff. Just add compatibility and things under the hood to improve performance.         Seriously, stop ruining a good thing before you've gone too far, please.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: I am transitioning from Opera (legacy version) to Firefox, and frankly I'm flabbergasted by the incredibly non-intuitive, convoluted, multi-step way Firefox has to provide access to two basic functions of any browser : bookmarks and history.        It's absolutely incredible that there's no way to access one or the other with a single click. I have 4 different icons on my toolbar to that effect, and they still don't do the job (Bookmark this Page, Show your Bookmarks, Show your History and Show Sidebars). Not only do they overlap, but each of them has a different user interface logic. And that's a customised interface, not the default one.        The result is I never know where to click when I want to do something bookmark or history-related.        What's required (and that other browsers have been providing for, what ? a decade ?) is :        1. One click, and I'm presented with the full folder structure of my bookmarks, in a stable and workable window (not nested menus popping up unexpectedly all over the place). That could be on the left pane, à la Windows Explorer, which is a true and tried convention that everybody understands ; or it could be splashed over a full tab, following a more modern convention.        2. One click, and I'm presented with my full history, with calendar help. Again, it could be on the left pane, in a tab or elsewhere, but a in big, fixed working space.        3. Optionally, if commands 1 and 2 don't give access to all relevant functions, a one-click access to the full-fledged management of bookmarks and history (the equivalent of the Library window).  1 and 2 would be for browsing, bookmarking pages and quick file management on the fly, and 3 would be for more thorough file management, search, backup, etc.        Of course, you should be able to switch in one click between 1, 2 and 3, wherever you are and wherever you want to go. It's absolutely incredible, for instance, that when I'm in Bookmarks (left pane), there's no link to go from there to the Library (which is just an expansion of Bookmarks). It has already taken me 2 clicks to get there, and now I have to back off from that area of the screen, climb again to the toolbar, guess the appropriate icon, and click again... twice ! Either Show your Bookmarks / Show all Bookmarks, or Show your History / Show all History.        The fact that there are multiple paths for the same effect increases the confusion. The wording of commands is deceptive. Show all Bookmarks doesn't do that at all, because the lesser option, Show Sidebars / Bookmarks, already shows all bookmarks in the left pane. What's specific in the Show all Bookmarks windows (Library) is that you can manage your bookmarks to the max -- and your history, which means that you should not have a different wording for Show all Bookmarks and Show all History, because they point to the same window (Library), only with a different folder pre-selected.        A better wording would be, for instance : Bookmarks / History / Manage Bookmarks and History.        By the way, you click into Show all Bookmarks, and a window opens which is called... Library ! How intuitive is that ?    When you click on Show your Bookmarks, the expanded option Show all Bookmarks is near the top of the drop-down menu (and also on the bottom : confusion, again !). But when you click on the (very similar) icon Show your History, in order to get to the expanded option Show all History, you have to go down to the bottom of the menu ! Not one thing is consistent, in that interface !        I know there are keyboard shortcuts, but that's an acquired taste, and their use shouldn't be compulsory.        I have chosen to hide menus, because they don't provide the solution and add to the confusion. The address bar does a great guessing job by mining the data in Bookmarks and History, but you can't rely only on that, and in order for it to find a bookmark, you have to file it first (and maintain the file system).        There might be extensions relevant to this issue (I've found a single one, it's clunky, and it solves one tiny part of the problem), but this is something that the barebones browser should provide out of the box.

When you backup your computer you can see what has been backed up and this should be the same with FF. Could you please help me so I may view the backed up bookmarks? user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64; rv:42.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/42.0
description: I just downgraded from 43 to 42 to keep the ability to toggle browser.search.showOneOffButtons to preserve the "classic" search bar behavior that has already been non-default for several versions. Here is how I use the search bar while using the drop-down menu to select my search engine beforehand:    1. Controlling which search engine provides search suggestions as I type, which also includes controlling which search engine sees my incomplete queries as a basis for making suggestions.    2. Controlling which search engine will handle a search from the context menu after selecting text.    3. Seeing at a glance which search engine Firefox is currently configured to use.    3a. Knowing immediately if Firefox unilaterally changes my default search engine (a behavior for which, regrettably, precedent exists).    4. Performing partial searches in which the desired information appears in the search suggestions, providing my answer without leaving my current page (for example, simple arithmetic using Google's calculator functionality).        All of these use cases are broken by the new behavior of the search bar.

description: I recently updated my firefox (I rarely do) and I was just now introduced to the "New Tab" thing (I would've called it "functionality or feature but that is here definitely not the case). I feel like I gave my car to it's general inspection and when picking it up again the mechanic tells me "Hey your windscreen now looks a lot more beautiful, but we had to scrap the ignition. I have no words for the decision to just disable this feature and I seriously hope this will be fixed before I found a good replacement browser, otherwise it's my time wasted and one less user for you.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Please fix the problem the browser has begun to have with the last two updates in that it will not stay in maximized (F11) mode. I strongly prefer to have the browser to remain maximized. You did such a nice job allowing the address and search bar to re-appear by hovering my mouse at the top of the screen. With the last two updates, the screen does not stay maximized. Changing pages almost always causes the Windows task bar to re-appear along the bottom and once there it remains. Similarly, using the address bar (either address or search) causes the top to have the tabs come into view. Once either of these two things happen, full screen cannot be restored without hitting F11 twice. This was not a problem until about a month ago. Please fix this such that the browser will stay maximized. As a further request, can you allow me to delete the Search line which appears at the top of any addresses returned when I use the address bar? I have a Search box for that. I do not need two and it is distracting to always have to move past this newly added Search line in the Suggestions appearing as I type an address. Thank you.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: This new firefox forced addon signing is breaking addons for older programs which still work, but would never be updated -- i.e. old Pdf printer addons and others. I understand that eventually all addons will become obsolete, but this digital signature is an unnecessary step to obsolescence, and actually harms knowledgeable users. Also some more obscure addons such as upoopu for the online game Utopia are also broken for weeks now. Please add an option to allow the addon despite the missing signature. I understand many people are oblivious to the risks involved, but some of us know what we're doing and don't appreciate this forced nanny watching. You can always add a checkbox to agree to a waiver before addons are enabled.

description: Firefox definitely makes me happy! Except right now, in this one little way. (And maybe a few other little ways, but overwhelmingly, Firefox makes me quite happy.) I'm on the about:addons page, and the very first "Featured Add-on" is Tab Notifier. Which does sound pretty nifty at first glance. Then I noticed that it hasn't been updated since Nov. 2014. And the support blog hasn't been touched since 2012. (Early 2012!) This does not appear to be an add-on that is getting much love, and that makes me quite uncomfortable. I get that it still works on many systems much of the time, but I do not think it should be given the implied "Firefox Stamp of Approval" unless it's still on the developer's radar -- especially in light of a major OS update. Thanks!

description: Overall, Firefox is the best and fastest browser compared to Chrome, IE or Edge. It is my default browser. Edge is the slowest browser & the easiest to be hijacked, lock-up or compromise your privacy/security. I've had this happen numerous times & sent feedback. I visited websites that displayed ads & items I just viewed from sites previously visited while browsing "IN PRIVATE". PDF support is awful too.    I couldn't access my bookmarks in Chrome unless I log-in to Google first. It doesn't respect privacy and let's you know this by plastering thumbnails of every website that you visited across the browser.     I have suggestions on how to improve Firefox. This is the only avenue I could find to do so since there is no "Send Feedback" link on the browser. The bookmark operation should be changed. I can't save new bookmarks. My bookmarks keep getting sorted in alphabetical order. I can't delete unused bookmarks. I learned that the bookmarks are a write protected file. That is the default setting. I read the procedure to unlock it, but it is too lengthy, complicated & confusing. Locked bookmarks should not be the default setting. I left the bookmarks alone and have to live without adding new ones until a new version appears to correct this. They show up in "Recently Bookmarked", but they eventually disappear while others that I never bookmarked appear & replace them. I liked the way IE Favorites worked. It was simple to use & manage. A suggestion for a new feature is to prevent websites from viewing your bookmarks. Bookmarks should be "Read Protected".  This is an invasion of privacy. I don't know them or want them to profile me. That's not their business. I don't have access to any of their personal information, why should they have access to mine. I would like to see bookmark access denied unless it allowed by the user. Also, the icon adjacent to bookmarks gets deleted when the computer is re-booted. Not good.    I visit Yahoo News and send articles of interest to open in new tabs to be read later. Edge used to slow down & lock up doing this. Firefox is very fast & stable. One thing that has happened is; sometimes a new pop-up window is opened playing a video ad. I didn't know this until I heard sound from my speakers. One time, several tabs were opened doing the same thing. I'm sure this new generation Pop-Up can be blocked. It is an unwanted nuisance.    One more item. When I read my email from Ebay, the suggested items are blocked & can't be viewed. There should be an option to "View All Images". I have to read this email in IE to see the image suggestions.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Greetings!    Just for fun, I'll include my email address so we can communicate if you like. That might be cool.    I hope you are having a fantastic holiday season, and you're packing in as much fun as possible--because after Jan 1, you'll probably be shuffled back to the most secure rehab clinic in the nation.    Anyone who runs a company that forces products that Don't Work on customers and expects nothing to come of it is either clinically insane, or chemically unbalanced well beyond anything Cortney Love or Jim Morrison considered reasonable.    No, really.    Do YOU people ever deal with your plugin container? Do YOU people ever go to Your Own plugin update page, update everything to only see that Your Own Page says you still need to update? Have YOU people ever tried to communicate with anyone at MozFf Through Your Own Website?    Yes, I know--It's the Holiday Season and everyone should be Merry and all that...    But when I'm doing Everything I Can to get my computer off the ground and YOU people are apparently doing everything you can to keep me from doing that--because of your own ineptitude, well...Someone has to say Something.    Call it "tough love"--or give it some other name, but the bottom line is, YOUR bottom line is going to Bottom Out if You Don't Get Your Act Together and Start Fixing Your Own Problems.    What the Hell is Wrong with you people?    You create something called "plugin container" and you have angered and outraged people Across The Globe--and you STILL haven't figured out a way to Fix The Problems It Causes?    When did you people Start Celebrating the holidays, anyway? Five Years Ago?    What is your Liquor Tab?    How can you Afford so many failed trips to Rehab?    And Who designed your Contact Us maze?    Did you think I was going to travel from NC to San Francisco to just stop by and see if anyone was actually alive in your office?    And what kind of Brain-Damaged War are you fighting with Kaspersky and the Adobe Flash people? Who is Stupid Enough to fight with companies that service the people YOU RELY ON?    Are You In There, Mozilla Firefox People?    Don't get me wrong.    I certainly do not expect a response from anyone at Mozilla Firefox, particularly from anyone in a position of responsibility. Hell, we know they've apparently been locked away in the top three floors of the most expensive hotel in Honolulu since at least 2013, and the only people who have seen them are top security officials who pretend not to notice the traffic in and out of the elevators--the fat, scruffy thugs with expensive brief cases and the party people...    It's horrible, but it would be perfect for and episode of Dateline NBC.    But it would be FUN to forward this message to whomever calls him or herself a kind of "boss" or "director"--just to have it documented that someone at MozFf actually cared--and Tried to warn them, before Reality rolls in like a typhoon and blows them out of their penthouse suites--and rips the bottoms out of everyone's bank accounts, because people assume alternatives to MozFf and the business evaporates like Eastern Airlines, and it becomes a humorous memory like "Alta Vista".    By now, I imagine that you have surmised the gist of this text--so I'll not bore you with further expressing what is very obvious to more people than you can count.    In the past, I admit that I Enjoyed MozFf. But now, you're Bloated, Disappointing, Slow and Smug. Your nauseating Smiley/Frowny Face prompts that led to this page proves it.    I'd rather run into online trouble with an entity full of Smart People Who Care, rather than continue struggling with mistakenly proud people who really couldn't care less if their business thrived or died--and apparently couldn't repair their products if they tried.    The End.

user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0
description: Please bring back the browser.search.showOneOffButtons functionality. I've been using Firefox since 2002, and the way the search bar works now is infuriating. The way I would like it to work would be to have the default search engine to reset on every browser restart to a pre-set site (eg. Google Search). I then like to have the ability to manually adjust the default search engine to a different engine, say IMDB, but without going to the Options screen, because that's exactly what the old functionality provided. Then, I can right-click any selected text, and search with MY chosen engine. When I do research, I often have to make multiple word/sentence searches from a single paragraph of plain text using several different search engines, and starting v43 I'm forced to manually copy everything into the search bar and then click on the search engine. This is very clunky experience, and pisses me off every time I have to do it, so please bring back the old functionality, I hope you don't expect your users to go through the Options screen every time they want to change their search engine.
